date_range: Tuesday 21 April 2015 13:00 () - Tuesday 21 April 2015 13:00 ()
time_range: Tuesday 21 April 2015, 13:00 (Europe/London) - Tuesday 21 April 2015 13:00 (Europe/London)
title: Analyzing, Annotating, and Linking RNA Data to Create Knowledge and Facilitate Research

field_person_biography.safe_value: Dr Anton Petrov joined EMBL-EBI in 2013 to help develop RNAcentral, a public database of non-coding RNA sequences. In 2015 he became Project Leader of RNA Resources, including RNAcentral and Rfam, a database that classifies non-coding RNAs into families. Originally from St.Petersburg, Russia, Anton completed his PhD with Prof. Neocles Leontis in Bowling Green State University, Ohio, USA, where he built databases and web applications for RNA 3D structure analysis.

field_long_description.safe_value: Linking and integrating diverse RNA data resources is crucial for deepening our understanding about RNA sequence, structure, function, and evolution, while also facilitating knowledge discovery for practical applications, such as RNA design for nanotechnology and nanomedicine. Atomic-resolution 3D data of highly structured RNA molecules, like ribosomal RNAs, riboswitches, and ribozymes, are rapidly accumulating. These data, appropriately integrated, are relevant for understanding many other RNA molecules since the potential for 3D structure can be as important as the sequence, even for molecules such as mRNAs, where the sequence-encoded information is central to function but structured regions can serve to modulate the translation of that information in important ways. I will use 16S rRNA as an example to illustrate the characteristics of structured RNA molecules and ways of visualizing, analyzing, and annotating RNA structures at different levels of organization, from pairwise interactions to recurrent local motifs (hairpin, internal and junction loops) to domains and folds. I will review the challenges and successes of visualising structural annotations on 2D diagrams, connecting sequence alignments with structures, and the need for automated tools to assist in comparative analysis. A major issue is integrated access to the different forms of RNA data by diverse users in ways that facilitate knowledge discovery. A key challenge is that their use is currently limited by the familiarity of users with the specialized software tools for accessing, interpreting, and assessing the quality of those data. Ways are needed to overcome these barriers to provide actionable information to diverse users regardless of their scientific backgrounds.

date_range: Tuesday 5 May 2015 13:00 () - Tuesday 5 May 2015 13:00 ()
time_range: Tuesday 5 May 2015, 13:00 (Europe/London) - Tuesday 5 May 2015 13:00 (Europe/London)
title: How do genes jump: insights from crystal structures and more…

field_person_biography.safe_value: Dr Alex Bateman joined EMBL-EBI as the Head of Protein Sequence Resources in 2012. He took over from Rolf Apweiler as the PI for the UniProt grant (an international collaboration between EBI, SIB and PIR) and has oversight for protein and ncRNA related databases at EMBL-EBI. Prior to that he managed the production of numerous popular biological databases such as Pfam and Rfam at the Sanger Institute. He was formerly a member of, and Chairman of the ISB's Executive Committee. He was also Executive Editor for Bioinformatics and Editor of NAR's database issue.

field_long_description.safe_value: Transposons constitute a large fraction of modern genomes and play important roles in evolution, adaptation, and disease development. Their ability to autonomously move around in and between genomes makes them also powerful genetic engineering tools. However, their molecular mechanisms are still poorly understood. Our lab uses microbial genetics, biochemistry, cell biology, and structural biology methods to study transposition mechanisms. In my seminar, I will present novel insights into the mechanisms of two transposons: the popular vertebrate genetic engineering tool, Sleeping Beauty (SB), and a vancomycin resistance conferring conjugative transposon (CTn). For Sleeping Beauty, we have reconstituted how the element encoded transposase enzyme cleaves the transposon ends in vitro, and showed that the initial assembly steps of transposition follow a distinct pathway, different from better-studied homologues like Human Mariner 1 or Mos1. We have also determined the first crystal structure of the SB transposase catalytic domain, which provides important insights into the mechanism of target DNA recognition and integration. I will also show how our novel structure explains hyperactive mutations in the SB transposase and allows us to engineer further improved variants. Conjugative transposons (CTns) provide an efficient mechanism to transmit antibiotic resistance genes across bacterial populations greatly contributing to the spread of antibiotic resistance, one of the greatest health challenges of the 21st century. They often sequester antibiotic resistance or virulence genes and can autonomously move these from the genome of one bacterium to another. I will present how we reconstitute the initial steps of the mobilization of a prototypical CTn and determine the first structure of a CTn integrase – DNA complex. Our results provide insights into long debated questions regarding the mechanism of conjugative transposition, and might, on the long term, help develop novel approaches to fight the spread of antibiotic resistance.

date_range: Tuesday 12 May 2015 13:00 () - Tuesday 12 May 2015 13:00 ()
time_range: Tuesday 12 May 2015, 13:00 (Europe/London) - Tuesday 12 May 2015 13:00 (Europe/London)
title: Genetic and epigenetic alterations in patients with congenital heart disease

field_long_description.safe_value: An overview of regulatory circuits establishing the cardiac transcriptome will be shown. A particular focus is the interaction between different molecular levels, involving epigenetic, transcriptional and post-transcriptional mechanisms. Beside the study of mouse models, we apply high-throughput technology to gain insights into congenital heart disease with a particular interest on Tetralogy of Fallot (ToF). More than ten years ago we provided the first genome-wide expression profiles of normal and diseased human hearts. More recently, we showed that ToF is an oligogenetic disorder and most interestingly mutated genes are key factor of SHF differentiation, and we predict that impaired differentiation and proliferation capacity of SHF progenitors is one main impact on the dys-developed. In addition, we just conducted a genome-wide study of DNA methylation alteration. We linked DNA methylation with genome-wide expression data and found a significant overlap for hypermethylated promoters and down-regulated genes, and vice versa. Among the differentially methylated genes with distinct expression changes are the sarcomeric component TNNI1, the co-receptor TDGF1, the endothelin converting enzyme ECE2, and the cytochrome C oxidase assembly protein SCO2. Moreover, we found examples of methylation changes co-localized with novel, differential splicing events among sarcomeric genes. Finally, we demonstrate the interaction of differentially methylated and expressed genes in TOF with mutated CHD genes in a molecular network. In order to perform functional follow up studies, we currently apply human iPSCs technology and their differentiation to cardiomyocytes

date_range: Tuesday 19 May 2015 13:00 () - Tuesday 19 May 2015 13:00 ()
time_range: Tuesday 19 May 2015, 13:00 (Europe/London) - Tuesday 19 May 2015 13:00 (Europe/London)
title: Exploiting spatial patterns in the analysis of ChIP-Seq and BS-Seq data.

field_person_biography.safe_value: PhD in Physics, University of Cambridge, 2009. Postdoctoral Fellow, Max Planck Institutes Tübingen, 2009–2012. Research Group Leader at EMBL-EBI since 2012.

field_long_description.safe_value: Deep sequencing technologies are routinely employed to probe protein-DNA interactions and other epigenetic modifications such as DNA methylation. These technologies return complex results in the form of binding profiles which can be extended over several kilobases and present characteristic spatial patterns. Such patterns appear to be reproducible among replicates, yet how they can be incorporated in a formal statistical analysis of the data is non-trivial. In this talk I will introduce MMDiff, a kernel-based statistical methodology to test for changes in spatial patterns in ChIP-Seq peaks. I will show how MMDiff analysis helped us formulate mechanistic hypotheses on the role of transcription factor proteins in the establishment of histone marks, which we later showed to be consistent with a large-scale analysis of the ENCODE data sets. Finally, if there is time, I will introduce M3D, an extension of MMDiff to DNA methylation profiles obtained with bisulfite-sequencing experiments. References: Schweikert et al, MMDiff: quantitative testing for shape changes in ChIP-Seq data sets, BMC Genomics 14:826 (2013) Benveniste et al, Transcription factor binding predicts histone modifications in human cell lines, PNAS, 111(37) 13367-72 (2014) Mayo et al, M3D: a kernel based test for spatially correlated changes in methylation profiles, Bioinformatics, in press.

date_range: Tuesday 9 June 2015 13:00 () - Tuesday 9 June 2015 13:00 ()
time_range: Tuesday 9 June 2015, 13:00 (Europe/London) - Tuesday 9 June 2015 13:00 (Europe/London)
title: Hidden Markov Models Tailored Towards Detecting Disease-causing Single Amino Acid Polymorphisms

field_person_biography.safe_value: Dr Alex Bateman joined EMBL-EBI as the Head of Protein Sequence Resources in 2012. He took over from Rolf Apweiler as the PI for the UniProt grant (an international collaboration between EBI, SIB and PIR) and has oversight for protein and ncRNA related databases at EMBL-EBI. Prior to that he managed the production of numerous popular biological databases such as Pfam and Rfam at the Sanger Institute. He was formerly a member of, and Chairman of the ISB's Executive Committee. He was also Executive Editor for Bioinformatics and Editor of NAR's database issue.

field_long_description.safe_value: The next generation sequencing technologies are continuously improving and large sets of human mutations are becoming available within institutions (e.g., research hospitals) and through public resources. A subset of these mutations lead to single amino acid polymorphisms (SAPs). Several computational methods have been developed to predict whether a SAP is linked to disease phenotype or not. Since the conservation of amino acids is typically attributed to their important structural or functional roles, these computational methods factor in evolutionary conservation of the amino acids as a critical element in accessing SAPs’ disease-causing impact. My lab currently focuses on development of method towards detection of disease-causing SAPs through assessment of amino acid conservation using Hidden Markov Models(HMMs). To this end, we have been conducting experiments on identifying ways to build these libraries from scratch or by leveraging existing resources such as HMM-based protein family classification databases. In my talk, I will first report on our evaluation of HMM-based protein family classification databases, as of the shelf products, in detecting conservation of amino acids at disease-causing SAP sites. I will then report on our experiments for computing optimal multiple sequence alignments, and the corresponding HMMs, using a disease-causing SAP benchmark set collected from various public resources including UniProt Knowledgebase.

date_range: Tuesday 23 June 2015 13:00 () - Tuesday 23 June 2015 13:00 ()
time_range: Tuesday 23 June 2015, 13:00 (Europe/London) - Tuesday 23 June 2015 13:00 (Europe/London)
title: Translating gene discovery efforts into primary prevention and drug discovery: Multiple Sclerosis and Alzheimer's disease

field_person_biography.safe_value: PhD in Medical Informatics, University of Wales, 1988. Imperial Cancer Research Fund, 1987–1995. UK Bioinformatics Manager, GlaxoWellcome R&D Ltd., 1995–1999. Vice President, Informatics, Pharmagene, 1999–2001. Managing Consultant, Sagentia Ltd., 2001-2009. At EMBL-EBI since 2006 (secondment 2006-2009).

field_long_description.safe_value: As the phase of gene discovery using genome-wide association studies come to an end, the process of translating these discoveries into clinically meaningful resources is accelerating. Using multiple sclerosis (MS) and Alzheimer's disease (AD), we will discuss approaches to address different, complementary to approaches disease management. In MS, the identification of over 150 susceptibility variants lacks clinical utility but is a key element of a new effort to map the sequence of events linking risk factors to clinical syndrome. The Genes & Environment in MS project is a social media-powered cohort of over 2,653 MS family members that provides a platform for both understanding prodromal MS pathophysiology and the testing of interventions for primary prevention. In AD, deep antemortem and postmortem phenotypic characterization paired with genetic, epigenomic and transcriptomic characterization of the target (brain) tissue in up to 1000 subjects has enabled the construction of a new generation of AD susceptibility network maps through the support of the NIH Accelerating Medicines Partnership. Validation of insights derived from these networks in iPSC-derived neurons, astrocytes, and microglia-like cells are driving the design of small molecule discovery efforts to identify lead compounds for AD.

title: Small ORFs: the interface between coding and non-coding RNA

field_person_biography.safe_value: Dr Alex Bateman joined EMBL-EBI as the Head of Protein Sequence Resources in 2012. He took over from Rolf Apweiler as the PI for the UniProt grant (an international collaboration between EBI, SIB and PIR) and has oversight for protein and ncRNA related databases at EMBL-EBI. Prior to that he managed the production of numerous popular biological databases such as Pfam and Rfam at the Sanger Institute. He was formerly a member of, and Chairman of the ISB's Executive Committee. He was also Executive Editor for Bioinformatics and Editor of NAR's database issue.

field_long_description.safe_value: DNA sequences encoding Small Open Reading Frames (smORFs) of fewer than 100 amino acids (aa) exist in each eukaryotic genome in numbers several orders of magnitude higher than the corresponding annotated protein-coding genes. Due to difficulties with bioinformatic detection and experimental analysis, along with their sheer numbers, smORFs have been ignored for a long time by mainstream genomics. However, thanks to recent advances in bioinformatic and experimental techniques smORFs are receiving increasing attention. Extensive use of RNA-Seq has shown that thousands of smORFs are transcribed, in many cases, in putative non-coding RNAs, and ribosomal profiling has detected translation of a few hundreds of these. I will discuss the challenges in defining translation of these novel smORFs in lncRNAs and UTRs, including the bioinformatic and biochemical approaches used to independently corroborate real translation events; the known functions of peptides produced by translated smORFs; and the possibility that many more smORFs are functional, but remain uncharacterised

field_person_biography.safe_value:
PhD in Computer Science, Moscow State University, 1987. Postdoctoral research at New Mexico State University, USA. At EMBL-EBI since 1997.

Dr Alvis Brazma oversees the development and services for several major resources, including ArrayExpress, the Gene Expression Atlas and the BioStudies Database. His main research interests concern integrative data analysis to reveal patterns of gene and protein expression in normal and diseased state. He has over 100 scientific publications and is a Principal Investigator on several large collaborative genomics and biomedical projects, including the kidney cancer project of the International Cancer Genome Consortium. Dr Brazma studied mathematics at the University of Latvia, Riga, before obtaining his PhD in computer science from the Moscow State University. He was a lecturer at the University of Latvia and a visiting Researcher at Helsinki University before joining EMBL-EBI in 1997. Dr Brazma was among the first scientists to use microarray data to study gene regulation. In 1999 he founded the Microarray Gene Expression Data society was instrumental in starting ArrayExpress, one of the major international repositories for functional genomics data.

title: Coordination of progenitor specification and growth in the developing spinal cord

field_person_biography.safe_value:
PhD 2000, University of Cambridge and MRC Laboratory of Molecular Biology. Trinity College Junior Research Fellow, 1999-2005. Beit Memorial Fellow for Biomedical Research, University College London, 2000-2001. MRC Career Track Programme Leader, MRC Laboratory of Molecular Biology, 2001-5 and MRC Programme Leader, 2006-12. Fellow and Director of Studies, Trinity College, since 2005. Principle Research Associate at the Dept Physics/Cavendish Laboratory, University of Cambridge, 2013-2016. Group Leader at EMBL-EBI and Sanger Institute since 2013.

Dr Sarah Teichmann is a research group leader at EMBL-EBI and senior group leader at the Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute. She is also a Principle Research Associate in the Dept Physics/Cavendish Laboratory, and a fellow of Trinity College, Cambridge. She is a leader in systems biology, which aims to explain how individual molecules within a cell co-operate to produce the cell’s overall behaviour. Her research also offers new insights into how proteins behave. This work could help scientists to predict how proteins interact with each other and design drugs that can interfere with disease processes. After reading the Natural Science Tripos at Trinity College, University of Cambridge, Sarah received her PhD in computational biology from the UK’s Medical Research Council Laboratory of Molecular Biology (MRC-LMB) in Cyrus Chothia's group. Sarah then moved to University College London as a Beit Memorial Fellow in Janet Thornton's group, where her work shed light on how proteins are formed from combinations of basic modules, and how they form networks of interactions in metabolic pathways. She returned to the LMB to set up her own group in 2001, where she focused on transcription factors, proteins that help to control the activity of genes. This included building a database (http://www.transcriptionfactor.org/) that allows researchers to search for genes predicted to encode transcription factors. Seminal work has shown how proteins club together to form larger “machines”, or complexes, by assembling via ordered pathways, and part of this is a further database, 3DComplex.org. Sarah is a co-founder of the state-of-the-art Single Cell Genomics Centre, a joint EMBL-EBI/Sanger initiative to clarify how gene activity is controlled throughout single cells of different types. Her work has been recognized by a number of awards, including the Biochemical Society's Colworth Medal, the Lister Prize, the Royal Society Crick Lecture and membership of the European Molecular Biology Organisation.

field_long_description.safe_value:
In developing spinal cord, an elaborate
pattern of multiple domains of molecularly distinct neuronal precursor
cells is established along the DV axis. This pattern depends both on the
dynamics of a morphogen-regulated
gene regulatory network, and the effects of tissue growth. To address
how these processes are coordinated we generated high-resolution
three-dimensional quantitative datasets of morphogen signaling and the
expression of key patterning genes in the mouse and
chick neural tube. We show that during development the gene expression
domains undergo characteristic changes in size that do not scale with
changes in overall tissue size, nor with alterations in morphogen
signaling. Instead proportions are sequentially controlled
by two different mechanisms. Initially, signaling by opposing morphogen
gradients establishes pattern. The precision of positional information
encoded by the opposing gradients is maximal during this phase.
Subsequently, cell-type specific regulation of differentiation
rate, but not proliferation, elaborates the pattern. Experimental tests
support this model. Furthermore, comparison of embryos of different
sizes reveals that regulation of the differentiation rate is key to
understanding the robustness of domain proportions
to both intra- and interspecies variations in size. Thus the sequential
control of progenitor specification and differentiation elaborates
pattern without requiring that signaling gradients grow as tissues
expand.

field_long_description.safe_value:
The Cambridge Immunology Network has been designed to create a sense of community amongst researchers active in immunology at Cambridge University and its affiliated institutions such as the EMBL-EBI and Sanger Institute. 

Dr Janine Wilkinson will introduce herself as the new coordinator and explain how the network is operating to help both early career and senior scientists to make the most of their research opportunities. Janine is keen to find out what researchers want from an academic support network and any ideas to improve the network will be welcome.

field_long_description.safe_value:
The main goal of the day is to gather all EBI postdocs and give everybody a rough idea of who's doing what.

As in recent editions of the postdocs day, we will have long and generous breaks to encourage discussions and exchanges.

This edition will also feature a talk from the most recent research group leader (Moritz Gerstung), who will introduce some of his research and will also take part in a quick Q&A about the transition from postdoc to PI.

There will be prices for the best talks!

Please refer to the attached schedule for the full list of talks.

field_short_description.safe_value: EMBL-EBI Postdoc Day

field_person_biography.safe_value: I graduated in Biotechnology at the University of Firenze, with a thesis regarding the search of genes involved in chromate resistance in Pseudomonas. Later I took a Master Degree in Bioinformatics at the University of Bologna with a thesis (work done at the Nijmegen Center for Molecular Life Sciences, The Netherlands) on the study on regulatory networks in Lactococcus lactis. I did my PhD in Florence, in which I have studied comparative genomics of the nitrogen-fixing plant symbiont Sinorhizobium meliloti, as well as the integration of genomic and phenotypic data for microbial species. In my current post-doctoral project I am studying the impact of sequence variability on phenotypes, using the Escherichia coli as a model to build this approach. In particular, I am studying the impact of nucleotide substitutions, InDels and gene content variability on several molecular process, such as protein stability/function, transcriptional regulation and metabolism. The predictions are being reconciliated with phenotypic measures for several hundred strains of E. coli, in collaboration with Typas lab from EMBL.

title: Precision Medicine with Clinical Big Data

field_person_display_title.value: Associate Professor of Biomedical Informatics and Medicine

field_person_biography.safe_value: Josh Denny is an Associate Professor of Biomedical Informatics and Medicine where he has both clinical and research roles. His research focuses on using natural language processing to extract accurate phenotype identification from electronic medical record data to discover genome-phenome associations including the development of the EMR-based phenome-wide association (PheWAS).  He is member of several US consortia including the Electronic Medical Records and Genomics (eMERGE) Network, Pharmacogenomics Research Network (PGRN), and the Pharmacogenomics of very large populations (PGPop) network. Josh recently completed a sabbatical at the NIH where he served on the Precision Medicine Initiative working group (PMI) that has developed a detailed framework for building a national research cohort of 1 million or more Americans to move the concept of precision medicine into clinical practice.

field_short_description.safe_value: Josh Denny seminar will focus on his use of natural language processing techniques to extract genome-phenome relationships from electronic health records (EHRs) and how he applies these in Phenome-Wide Association (PheWAS) analyses. He will also discuss the central role data extraction from EHRs will play in the upcoming $200M Precision Medicine Initiative being launched in the US.

field_person_biography.safe_value:
Dr Helen Parkinson head of Molecular Archival Resources at EMBL-EBI and leads the Samples, Phenotypes and Ontologies team, delivering databases, data integration tools and ontologies for biomedicine. She is also Interim Team Leader for the Variation Archive team. Trained as a geneticist, Helen's research focused on Drosophila biology, behaviour, molecular biology and medical genetics. In 1999 she shifted focus to bioinformatics and computational biology while performing positional cloning for primary pulmonary hypertension. Helen's passion is semantic data integration and providing users with useful data. Her team participates extensively in external collaborations ranging from data analysis and generation projects to infrastructural integration projects such as the ELIXIR initiatives BioMedBridges, CORBEL and EXELERATE. In collaboration with partners in the KOMP2 project and the International Mouse Phenotyping Consortium, Helen's SPOT team manages, analyses, and distributes complex phenotypic data from knockout mouse lines and promotes mouse data integration internationally.They also develop open-source software tools for managing data, developing and integrating ontologies and data, and integrating semantic web technologies.

Prior to joining EMBL-EBI in 2000, Helen was a post-doctoral researcher at the University of Leicester, where she worked on the genetic basis of Primary Pulmonary Hypertension, Hyphophatasia and synteny at human chromosomes 7 and 12. Her PhD thesis examined the temperature compensation of circadian rhythms in Drosophilawith Professor Bambos Kyriacou.

field_person_biography.safe_value: Efthymia Tsamoura received her BSc in 2007 and her PhD in 2013 both from the Computer Science Department of Aristotle University of Thessaloniki, Greece. Currently, she is a postdoctoral researcher in the Information Systems group of Oxford University, collaborating with Professor Michael Benedikt. Her research interests lie in the field of distributed query optimization, multi-objective query optimization and grid computing, while currently she is working on data integration and query answering under constraints. She is a co-author in 4 journal publications, 9 conferences (among which 1 VLDB and 1 PODS) and 3 book chapters. Dr Efthymia Tsamoura received several distinctions both during her undergraduate and postgraduate studies.

Rodrigo Lopez joined EMBL-EBI in 1996 as a systems administrator responsible for the deployment of scientific computing and became the External Services Team Leader in 2002. His Web Production team is responsible for the administration of the web infrastructure, development of core software services such as the EBI search engine and EMBL-EBI's job dispatcher, through which many sequence analysis tools run. Many project teams, both externally and within EMBL-EBI, depend on these developments. Rodrigo's team provides institute-wide support and advice on best practises to users. They are heavily involved in the support and in both technical and scientific training of the core software and systems they maintain. 

BSc In Veterinary Medicine, 1984, MSc Molecular Toxicology and Informatics 1987, University of Oslo. At EMBL-EBI since 1995

field_long_description.safe_value: Biologists need to query a multitude of different data resources in order to obtain useful insights. But how difficult is it to query multiple data sources? This talk delves into the factors that impact data integration, focusing on the ones that are frequently encountered in the web era. It then presents our vision for data integration and a platform that we have developed based on this vision. The last part of this talk presents data integration issues that we are studying. This part will also include a discussion of what the audience wants to see in an extension of the system.

field_long_description.safe_value: TET enzymes produce oxidized methylcytosines, which are intermediates in DNA demethylation as well as new epigenetic marks.  Mice acutely deleted for Tet3 in the context of a germline deletion of Tet2, and mice lacking both Tet2 and Tet3 in T cells, develop aggressive and myeloid and T cell cancers respectively.  TET function is also important for regulatory T cells.  I will describe these phenotypes and discuss the possible reasons.

title: Building the new Ontology Lookup Service with Neo4j

field_long_description.safe_value:
Data integration is intrinsic to how modern research is undertaken in areas such as genomics, drug development and personalised medicine. To better enable this integration a large number of biomedical ontologies have been developed by the community to provide common metadata vocabularies.  

There are now over one hundred biomedical ontologies in widespread use that describe concepts such as genes, molecules, drugs and diseases. This amounts to millions of terms that are interconnected via relationships that naturally form a graph of biological knowledge.  

The European Bioinformatics Institute (EMBL-EBI)  has been hosting a repository of these ontologies for the past 10 years and has recently undertaken a project to re-engineer this service from the ground up using the Spring Data Framework and Neo4j.

Simon will  discuss the design of the system and our rationale for choosing Neo4j. He will also discuss how this work relates to other activities in the area of linked data, RDF and semantics at the EBI.

Everyone welcome.

To RSVP (useful as we may need a bigger room) and for more information available please go to:

http://www.meetup.com/Genome-Campus-Software-Craftsmanship-Community/events/226392291

Prior to joining EMBL-EBI in 2011, Simon worked in research at the University of Manchester, AstraZeneca and the European Arabidopsis Stock Centre. His undergraduate degree is in biochemistry, and he holds an MSc in Computer Science from the University of Wales, Aberystwyth.

title: Improving the diagnostic yield in clinical genetics by recycling publicly available RNA-seq data

field_person_biography.safe_value: PhD in Physics, University of Cambridge, 2009. Postdoctoral Fellow, Max Planck Institutes Tübingen, 2009–2012. Research Group Leader at EMBL-EBI since 2012.

field_long_description.safe_value:
While a lot of progress in next generation sequencing has been made in
the last few years, still less than 50% of the patients who are being
referred to a clinical geneticists eventually get diagnosed: often
variants of unknown significance show up, making it difficult to draw
firm conclusions. In order to gain insight on the potentially
detrimental molecular consequences of such variants and the genes they
affect, we are currently using expression quantitative trait locus
(eQTL) mapping and allele specific expression analysis in various
different cohorts, comprising in total 50,000 samples (including the
Transcriptome of the Netherlands, a population based RNA-seq cohort of
5,000 peripheral blood samples). This enables us to link many (rare)
genetic variants to molecular effects on specific genes. We subsequently
use co-regulation data, derived from publicly available RNA-seq data to
predict whether any of those genes likely cause the disease of
interest. This strategy has now enabled us to diagnose several patients
in our clinic, and might therefore be useful for other clinical
geneticists as well.

field_long_description.safe_value: T cell receptor proximal signalling represents a specific instance of a multisite phosphorylation system. Receptor phosphorylation is regulated by the opposing actions of the kinase LCK, and phosphatases such as CD45 and CD148. Particular phosphoforms recruit the kinase ZAP-70, which once bound, propagates downstream signalling. We seek to elucidate the functional consequences of multiple phosphorylation sites on the dose-response profiles of receptor phosphorylation. We combine mathematical modelling with cellular reconstitution to assess the effect of multiple modification sites on the potency and sensitivity of receptor phosphorylation. We find that multiple sites enhance the potency of receptor phosphorylation, but do not alter the sensitivity of dose-response profiles. This correlation between the number of sites and response potency is consistent with a mechanism whereby phosphorylation mediates an enhancement in the enzymatic efficiencies of modification.

field_long_description.safe_value: Photosynthetic gene expression in Rhodobacter sphaeroides is regulated in response to changes in light and redox conditions by three main systems; PrrB/A, FnrL and AppA/PpsR. Previously, we have developed a model of the AppA/PpsR system which we here propose to be primarily responsible for regulating changes in photosynthetic gene expression on the transition between aerobic and photosynthetic growth. We have developed a methodology for normalising and combining all publically available microarray datasets for this bacterium under diverse growth conditions. By extending our model to include the biological input of atmospheric oxygen concentration and an output of photosynthetic gene expression we can use the biological microarray data to parameterise our model. I will demonstrate that the AppA/PpsR system alone is capable of accounting for the observed trends in photosynthetic gene expression seen at different oxygen levels without the requirement to model the PrrB/A or FnrL systems. Using biological data to parameterise our model I will also show that the combination of parameters which fit the biological data for the AppA/PpsR system modelled here are broadly consistent with those which we previously determined were required for the system to show bistability in vivo.

field_person_biography.safe_value: Dr Anton Petrov joined EMBL-EBI in 2013 to help develop RNAcentral, a public database of non-coding RNA sequences. In 2015 he became Project Leader of RNA Resources, including RNAcentral and Rfam, a database that classifies non-coding RNAs into families. Originally from St.Petersburg, Russia, Anton completed his PhD with Prof. Neocles Leontis in Bowling Green State University, Ohio, USA, where he built databases and web applications for RNA 3D structure analysis.

RNA Seminars on December 1st

Location: Room C-302 (above DiNA)

field_short_description.safe_value: This RNA-themed seminar will consist of four short presentations which can be attended individually or in sequence. First Michelle Meyer (Boston College) will talk about using RNA regulators of ribosomal proteins as a model for structured RNA evolution, then Robin Gutell (University of Texas at Austin) will discuss comparative analysis of RNA structure and the Comparative RNA Website. Next, Maria Paraskevopoulou will present DIANA-TarBase and DIANA-LncBase databases that focus on miRNA-mRNA and lncRNA-mRNA interaction respectively. Anton Petrov (EMBL-EBI) will wrap up by talking about the latest developments in RNAcentral and Rfam databases.

field_abstract.value: RNA regulators are extraordinarily diverse across different bacterial lineages, and in several cases the same biological process is RNA-regulated in distantly related bacterial species, but with entirely distinct mechanisms that have no obvious similarities. In E. coli, over half of the ribosomal protein genes are regulated by structured portions of their own transcripts. These mRNA structures interact with specific ribosomal proteins enabling negative feedback of ribosomal protein synthesis. However, most of these RNA regulators are narrowly distributed to E. coli and its closest relatives. In other bacterial species, alternative RNA regulators often perform the same biological function. We utilize the collection RNA regulators responsible for regulating ribosomal protein synthesis as a model to explore factors that contribute to the diversity of RNA regulators produced by evolution. These include the ways in which apparently unrelated RNA sequences may form the same tertiary structure, the co-evolution of the RNA regulators with their ribosomal protein partners, and the selective advantage conferred by the regulator on the organism.

field_abstract.value:
Currently, thousands of miRNA-gene interactions have been experimentally identified. However, this wealth of information is fragmented in thousands of manuscripts and raw next-generation sequencing data sets. The DIANA-repositories TarBase (http://www.microrna.gr/tarbase) and LncBase (www.microrna.gr/LncBase) provide hundreds of thousands of manually curated and meticulously analyzed experimentally supported miRNA interactions with coding and non-coding transcripts respectively. 

DIANA-TarBase v7.0 enables users to easily identify positive or negative experimental results for more than half a million miRNA-mRNA interactions retrieved from published experiments on 394 different cell types. Tarbase has been integrated in ENSEMBL since 2013, substituting its in silico miRNA predicted targets track. 

DIANA-LncBase v2 on the other hand, includes more than 70,000 miRNA-lncRNA experimentally supported interactions, adding an extra layer of complexity to the miRNA-target interaction map. Information regarding miRNA-lncRNA regulation is supported for 66 different cell types, spanning 36 tissues for human and mouse. Database entries are coupled with accurate lncRNA expression information, derived from the analysis of more than 6 billion RNA-Seq reads. 

Tarbase and LncBase host extensive information and meta-data for tissue/cell type-specific miRNA interactions. Supported entries and metadata are derived from different direct/indirect specific or high-throughput experimental methodologies, across different treatments and conditions. The new database versions include also information for the primer sequences used for cloning experiments and exact transcriptome-wide miRNA binding region coordinates derived from thousands of reporter assays and an in-house analysis of more than 150 raw CLIP-Seq libraries. Databases indexing non-coding RNA properties have become essential tools to the understanding of their function. Such projects can enable the implementation of novel algorithms as well as the charting and deciphering of the complex RNA cosmos.

However, this wealth of information is fragmented in thousands of manuscripts and raw next-generation sequencing data sets. The DIANA-repositories TarBase (http://www.microrna.gr/tarbase) and LncBase (www.microrna.gr/LncBase) provide hundreds of thousands of manually curated and meticulously analyzed experimentally supported miRNA interactions with coding and non-coding transcripts respectively. 

DIANA-TarBase v7.0 enables users to easily identify positive or negative experimental results for more than half a million miRNA-mRNA interactions retrieved from published experiments on 394 different cell types. Tarbase has been integrated in ENSEMBL since 2013, substituting its in silico miRNA predicted targets track. 

DIANA-LncBase v2 on the other hand, includes more than 70,000 miRNA-lncRNA experimentally supported interactions, adding an extra layer of complexity to the miRNA-target interaction map. Information regarding miRNA-lncRNA regulation is supported for 66 different cell types, spanning 36 tissues for human and mouse. Database entries are coupled with accurate lncRNA expression information, derived from the analysis of more than 6 billion RNA-Seq reads. 

Tarbase and LncBase host extensive information and meta-data for tissue/cell type-specific miRNA interactions. Supported entries and metadata are derived from different direct/indirect specific or high-throughput experimental methodologies, across different treatments and conditions. The new database versions include also information for the primer sequences used for cloning experiments and exact transcriptome-wide miRNA binding region coordinates derived from thousands of reporter assays and an in-house analysis of more than 150 raw CLIP-Seq libraries. Databases indexing non-coding RNA properties have become essential tools to the understanding of their function. Such projects can enable the implementation of novel algorithms as well as the charting and deciphering of the complex RNA cosmos.

field_person_biography.safe_value: Gutell received his Ph.D. from University of California-Santa Cruz in molecular biology. After a post-doc, he worked in several biotechnology companies, including Gen-Probe and Cangene. His research group uses computational biology and bioinformatics to study: RNA secondary and tertiary structure prediction with comparative sequence analysis; relationships between RNA sequences and their higher-order structures; RNA folding; and, RNA structure-based phylogenetic analysis. He also maintains a comparative RNA Web site, or knowledgbase, at www.rna.ccbb.utexas.edu. See also Gutell's page on the Institute for Cellular and Molecular Biology Web site.

field_abstract.value: The RNA Resources at European Bioinformatics Institute is a new group that is comprised of RNAcentral (http://rnacentral.org), an international database of non-­coding RNA sequences, and Rfam (http://rfam.xfam.org), a database of RNA families. In this talk I will discuss the fourth release of RNAcentral which includes seven new Expert Databases (dictyBase, Greengenes, LNCipedia, Modomics, NONCODE, PomBase, and SILVA) as well as RNA modifications from PDB and Modomics. I will also give a status update about Rfam and discuss future directions for both projects.

title: Genetic basis of variation in gene regulatory elements and its link to complex diseases

field_person_biography.safe_value: PhD in Physics, University of Cambridge, 2009. Postdoctoral Fellow, Max Planck Institutes Tübingen, 2009–2012. Research Group Leader at EMBL-EBI since 2012.

field_long_description.safe_value: Genome-wide association studies (GWAS) have uncovered thousands of correlations between genetic variants and complex human diseases. Unfortunately, the majority of these disease-associated variants lie in the non-coding part of the genome, which makes is very difficult to understand the underlying molecular mechanisms. Therefore, to gain a mechanistic understanding of complex genetic diseases, it is essential to understand how genetic variants affect gene regulation to understanding human disease. Gene regulation often involves long-range enhancer-promoter interactions, however it remains largely unknown to what extent genetic variants can act over long distances. Here we integrated chromatin-profiling data for promoter and enhancer histone marks in healthy individuals with physical chromatin interaction maps to study the long-range effect of genetic variants, which lets us propose molecular mechanisms of how variation on the DNA level is propagated to changes in gene expression.

title: HRF Talk:  Global Alliance for Genomics and Health (GA4GH)

field_long_description.safe_value:
The Global Alliance for Genomics and Health (Global Alliance) brings together over 300 leading institutions working in healthcare, research, life science, and information technology. The Sanger Institute is one of the three host institutions of the Global Alliance, along with The Broad Institute and the Ontario Institute of Cancer Research. The Wellcome Genome Campus is the largest hub of Global Alliance activity in the world.

 

The partners in the Global Alliance are working together to create a common framework of harmonised approaches to enable the responsible, voluntary, and secure sharing of genomic and clinical data. 

 

Come along to learn more about the Global Alliance, our campus activities and the Data Working Group which is the powerhouse of the Alliance.

time_range: Tuesday 8 December 2015, 10:00 (Europe/London) - Tuesday 8 December 2015 11:00 (Europe/London)
title: The Underlying Architecture of the Immune System: Modelling the Chromatin Landscape and Reconstructing the Regulatory Networks

field_person_biography.safe_value: PhD University of Cambridge, 1992. Postdoctoral work at National Institute for Medical Research, London, 1991-1995, and University of Cambridge, 1995-2002. Wellcome Trust Senior Fellow, 1995-2006. At EMBL-EBI since 2002. EMBL Senior Scientist since 2009.

field_long_description.safe_value:
With the rise of advanced high-throughput sequencing, the study of gene regulation has exploded with potential.  The field of immunology, in particular, has much to benefit from genomic  approaches.  From a single precursor, the hematopoietic stem cell (HSC), a plethora of cells with unique phenotypes and functions can develop.  In my work, we analyze genomic and epigenomic assays to investigate the role of regulatory networks underlying the myeloid lineage of the immune system in health and disease.  I will describe how we modeled the regulatory elements of tissue-resident macrophages to expose the impact of the cell’s microenvironment.  Using transplant experiments, we confirmed that the environmental  signals from the tissue were sufficient to recapitulate the specific chromatin landscape of the resident macrophages.  To study how these regulatory networks vary through development, we focused on the brain-resident macrophages, microglia, which are isolated from the rest of the hematopoietic system by the blood-brain barrier.  By characterizing microglia from yolk sac progenitors to the embryonic, newborn, and adult brain, we uncovered 3 distinct phases of development.  Perturbations of this precise timing can lead to neurodevelopmental defects.  On a separate timescale, differentiation of the myeloid lineage begins with the common myeloid progenitor (CMP).  Comparing single cell transcriptome analysis with the atlas of regulatory elements, we find that individual cells within the CMP population exhibit varying levels of commitment to their terminal fate.  In many cases, modeling the differential chromatin landscape can reveal both the history and potential of a cell population.  Using this data to reconstruct the underlying regulatory networks in the immune system is critical to understanding how they are perturbed in disease and to inform therapeutic treatments.

If you would like to meet with Debbie, please contact Zoe Higney (zhigney@ebi.ac.uk)

title: The JNK, JAK/STAT and Nrf2 pathways constitute the molecular signature of loser cells and contribute to distinct aspects of cell competition

field_person_affiliation.value: Department of Zoology, University of Cambridge

field_person_biography.safe_value:
PhD 2000, University of Cambridge and MRC Laboratory of Molecular Biology. Trinity College Junior Research Fellow, 1999-2005. Beit Memorial Fellow for Biomedical Research, University College London, 2000-2001. MRC Career Track Programme Leader, MRC Laboratory of Molecular Biology, 2001-5 and MRC Programme Leader, 2006-12. Fellow and Director of Studies, Trinity College, since 2005. Principle Research Associate at the Dept Physics/Cavendish Laboratory, University of Cambridge, 2013-2016. Group Leader at EMBL-EBI and Sanger Institute since 2013.

Dr Sarah Teichmann is a research group leader at EMBL-EBI and senior group leader at the Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute. She is also a Principle Research Associate in the Dept Physics/Cavendish Laboratory, and a fellow of Trinity College, Cambridge. She is a leader in systems biology, which aims to explain how individual molecules within a cell co-operate to produce the cell’s overall behaviour. Her research also offers new insights into how proteins behave. This work could help scientists to predict how proteins interact with each other and design drugs that can interfere with disease processes. After reading the Natural Science Tripos at Trinity College, University of Cambridge, Sarah received her PhD in computational biology from the UK’s Medical Research Council Laboratory of Molecular Biology (MRC-LMB) in Cyrus Chothia's group. Sarah then moved to University College London as a Beit Memorial Fellow in Janet Thornton's group, where her work shed light on how proteins are formed from combinations of basic modules, and how they form networks of interactions in metabolic pathways. She returned to the LMB to set up her own group in 2001, where she focused on transcription factors, proteins that help to control the activity of genes. This included building a database (http://www.transcriptionfactor.org/) that allows researchers to search for genes predicted to encode transcription factors. Seminal work has shown how proteins club together to form larger “machines”, or complexes, by assembling via ordered pathways, and part of this is a further database, 3DComplex.org. Sarah is a co-founder of the state-of-the-art Single Cell Genomics Centre, a joint EMBL-EBI/Sanger initiative to clarify how gene activity is controlled throughout single cells of different types. Her work has been recognized by a number of awards, including the Biochemical Society's Colworth Medal, the Lister Prize, the Royal Society Crick Lecture and membership of the European Molecular Biology Organisation.

field_long_description.safe_value:
Cell competition is a process by which a population of fitter cells (winners) outcompetes neighbouring weaker cells (losers), inducing their elimination by cell death or differentiation. Despite its discovery four decades ago, the molecular properties that earmark cells as losers have not been identified.

To determine the molecular differences between winner and loser cells we generated and analysed RNAseq data from winner (wild-type) cells and a subset of loser mutations, from Drosophila wing discs. To enrich for genes involved in the loser cell status, we focused on the intersection of genes that were differentially expressed in the loser mutants compared to wild-type. This intersection includes genes indicative of a constitutively activated stress response, encompassing JNK, JAK/STAT and oxidative stress response pathways.

Through functional characterisation we found that each stress signalling pathway regulates cell competition outcome via a distinct mechanism: JNK pathway activation in loser cells limits their growth potential; JAK/STAT pathway ligands boost non-autonomously the growth of winner cells; finally, the activation of the oxidative stress response is sufficient to induce loser cell killing by wild-type neighbours.

title: HRF seminar : Gene Expression Team - Horizon 2016

field_person_biography.safe_value: Robert Petryszak leads the Gene Expression team, which deals with the acquisition, curation, quality control, statistical analysis and visualisation of functional genomics data, as well as user support and training for ArrayExpress and the Expression Atlas. Previously, in the InterPro team, Robert led the development of a pipeline applying InterProScan software to all known protein sequences. Before joining EMBL-EBI in 2003, he enjoyed ten years of software development and technical management experience in a number of commercial and R&D technology organisations spanning expert systems, telecommunications, printing software and investment research. Robert received his MPhil in Computer Speech and Language Processing from the University of Cambridge in 1995.

field_long_description.safe_value: The Gene Expression team deals with the acquisition, curation, quality control, statistical analysis and visualisation of functional genomics data as well as user support and training for ArrayExpress and Expression Atlas. The size of the team and the range of our activities is growing - came along and learn more about our recent projects, and plans for 2016 - including e.g. gene co-expression, single-cell RNA-seq visualisation, differential methylation, and building the centre of excellence for RNA-seq and microarray analysis that will benefit many groups within EMBL-EBI and beyond.

title: Publishing, Open Data, & Open Access: How Open is Open?

field_person_biography.safe_value:
PhD 2000, University of Cambridge and MRC Laboratory of Molecular Biology. Trinity College Junior Research Fellow, 1999-2005. Beit Memorial Fellow for Biomedical Research, University College London, 2000-2001. MRC Career Track Programme Leader, MRC Laboratory of Molecular Biology, 2001-5 and MRC Programme Leader, 2006-12. Fellow and Director of Studies, Trinity College, since 2005. Principle Research Associate at the Dept Physics/Cavendish Laboratory, University of Cambridge, 2013-2016. Group Leader at EMBL-EBI and Sanger Institute since 2013.

Dr Sarah Teichmann is a research group leader at EMBL-EBI and senior group leader at the Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute. She is also a Principle Research Associate in the Dept Physics/Cavendish Laboratory, and a fellow of Trinity College, Cambridge. She is a leader in systems biology, which aims to explain how individual molecules within a cell co-operate to produce the cell’s overall behaviour. Her research also offers new insights into how proteins behave. This work could help scientists to predict how proteins interact with each other and design drugs that can interfere with disease processes. After reading the Natural Science Tripos at Trinity College, University of Cambridge, Sarah received her PhD in computational biology from the UK’s Medical Research Council Laboratory of Molecular Biology (MRC-LMB) in Cyrus Chothia's group. Sarah then moved to University College London as a Beit Memorial Fellow in Janet Thornton's group, where her work shed light on how proteins are formed from combinations of basic modules, and how they form networks of interactions in metabolic pathways. field_long_description.safe_value:
Open access publishing is now an accepted and often expected norm. However open access still comes in many flavours and it is important to question how open is open--a variety of different licenses permit or restrict reuse to very variable degrees. It is also no longer sufficient for a research article to be open access without also making the underlying data openly available. In a follow-on wave of scientific accountability, open data is also now a priority issue. An increasing awareness of the need for data management practises and the implementation of new policies at funders and publishers (including the PLOS Data Policy) are leading to a sea-change. We enter an era of transparency around research, reporting, data, peer review and this ties in with a push for scientists to make their results and research articles available to the public as soon as possible. PLOS encourages open peer review and preprint posting but there are lots of open questions here to explore (incentives, motivations, moderation etc.)—in this talk I’ll discuss and then welcome input and thoughts around the challenges and open questions.

 

If you'd like to meet Emma, please contact Tracey Andrew (tandrew@ebi.ac.uk) who will arrange a time.

title: Translating big data into molecular knowledge in imaging mass spectrometry and spatial multi-omics

field_person_display_title.value: Team Leader, Head of Metabolomics Core Facility

field_person_biography.safe_value:
PhD 2007, St. Petersburg State University.
Postdoctoral Researcher, University of Bremen.
Group Leader, University of Bremen.
Visiting Researcher, University of California San Diego.
Team leader at EMBL since 2014.

field_long_description.safe_value: Spatial metabolomics is emerging as a powerful approach to localize hundreds of metabolites directly from sections of biological samples or on biological surfaces. The grand challenges are in the visualization and molecular interpretation of big data generated to provide a mechanistic and systemic understanding of the analyzed biological systems. Existing bioinformatics tools cannot be applied directly because of the sheer size and high complexity of the data reaching hundreds of GBs per sample or individual. We will present new bioinformatics tools we developed in two projects. In the first project recently published in PNAS, we created molecular and microbial maps of the human skin surface by combining both mass spectrometry and 16S rRNA sequencing approaches. This allowed us to reveal that the molecular composition of skin has diverse distributions and that the composition is defined not only by skin cells and microbes but also by our daily routines, including the application of hygiene products. The developed software is available as a KNIME workflow and a Google Chrome app. In the European Horizon2020 project METASPACE, we are developing algorithms for molecular annotation for High Resolution Imaging Mass Spectrometry that integrate both spectral and spatial filters. We will present our efficient implementation using modern big data technologies and its applications it to 3D cell spheroids, microbial agar plates, and biological tissues. One major challenge that we addressed is the formulation of a False Discovery Rate applicable in the spatial metabolomics setting.

field_short_description.safe_value:
In the last ever HRF talk, come and learn a bit about the mass 
spectrometry based resources at the EBI: PRIDE (for proteomics data) and 
MetaboLights (for metabolomics). We will give you an integrated overview 
of the things we do and how both fields are increasingly working 
together. NMR will also be mentioned as a widely used approach in the 
metabolomics field. Finally, we will introduce OmicsDI, as a resource 
integrating different types of comics datasets.

title: Ultra-High-Throughput Single-Cell Genotyping and Phenotyping using Droplet-Based Microfluidics

field_person_biography.safe_value:
PhD 2000, University of Cambridge and MRC Laboratory of Molecular Biology. Trinity College Junior Research Fellow, 1999-2005. Beit Memorial Fellow for Biomedical Research, University College London, 2000-2001. MRC Career Track Programme Leader, MRC Laboratory of Molecular Biology, 2001-5 and MRC Programme Leader, 2006-12. Fellow and Director of Studies, Trinity College, since 2005. Principle Research Associate at the Dept Physics/Cavendish Laboratory, University of Cambridge, 2013-2016. Group Leader at EMBL-EBI and Sanger Institute since 2013.

Dr Sarah Teichmann is a research group leader at EMBL-EBI and senior group leader at the Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute. She is also a Principle Research Associate in the Dept Physics/Cavendish Laboratory, and a fellow of Trinity College, Cambridge. She is a leader in systems biology, which aims to explain how individual molecules within a cell co-operate to produce the cell’s overall behaviour. Her research also offers new insights into how proteins behave. This work could help scientists to predict how proteins interact with each other and design drugs that can interfere with disease processes. After reading the Natural Science Tripos at Trinity College, University of Cambridge, Sarah received her PhD in computational biology from the UK’s Medical Research Council Laboratory of Molecular Biology (MRC-LMB) in Cyrus Chothia's group. Sarah then moved to University College London as a Beit Memorial Fellow in Janet Thornton's group, where her work shed light on how proteins are formed from combinations of basic modules, and how they form networks of interactions in metabolic pathways. She returned to the LMB to set up her own group in 2001, where she focused on transcription factors, proteins that help to control the activity of genes. This included building a database (http://www.transcriptionfactor.org/) that allows researchers to search for genes predicted to encode transcription factors. Seminal work has shown how proteins club together to form larger “machines”, or complexes, by assembling via ordered pathways, and part of this is a further database, 3DComplex.org. Sarah is a co-founder of the state-of-the-art Single Cell Genomics Centre, a joint EMBL-EBI/Sanger initiative to clarify how gene activity is controlled throughout single cells of different types. Her work has been recognized by a number of awards, including the Biochemical Society's Colworth Medal, the Lister Prize, the Royal Society Crick Lecture and membership of the European Molecular Biology Organisation.

field_long_description.safe_value:
Programmable microfluidic modules have been created which can precisely make, combine, split, mix, incubate, detect fluorescence and sort microscopic droplets. Integration of multiple modules onto a single microfluidics chip enables a vast number of assays (>105 min-1) to be performed using extremely low volumes of reagents. Each microdroplet functions as an independent microreactor separated from both the walls of the device and other microdroplets by a fluorinated carrier fluid. The droplets function like the wells of microtitre plates but have volumes a thousand to a million times smaller.

This technology has many potential applications in fundamental research, industrial biotechnology, diagnostics and drug discovery. The advantages of screening using microfluidic screening systems is demonstrated graphically by a recent  ultra-high-throughput screening experiment in which ~108 individual enzyme reactions were screened in only 10 h, using <150 μL of reagents. Compared with state-of- the-art robotic, microtitre plate-based screening systems, the entire screen was performed with a 1,000-fold increase in speed and a significant reduction in reaction volumes and cost (the total cost of the screen was only $2.50, compared with $15 million using microplates).

The scale of the system is particularly well adapted to single-cell studies and combining this microfluidic technology with recent developments in next-generation sequencing has opened up a number of exciting opportumities, such as the high-throughput screening of non-immortalised B-cells for the discovery of therapeutic antibodies and the massively parallel analysis of single cells using DNA-seq, RNA-seq and ChIP-seq.

date_range: Tuesday 19 January 2016 16:00 () - Tuesday 19 January 2016 17:00 ()
time_range: Tuesday 19 January 2016, 16:00 (Europe/London) - Tuesday 19 January 2016 17:00 (Europe/London)
title: Direct assessment of sequence heterogeneity in human cancers by Duplex Sequencing

field_person_biography.safe_value: Moritz Gerstung leads a research group at EMBL-EBI investigating the underlying mechanisms of cancer development and seeking to understand the differences in therapy success and outcomes in different individuals. His team develops statistical models for relating different layers of genomic, molecular and clinical data to establish connections between genotype and phenotype, and tools to predict outcomes based on comprehensive, high-dimensional datasets. The group also explores the evolutionary dynamics of cancer. He has a PhD in Computational Biology from ETH Zurich (2012), and carried out postdoctoral work at the Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute (2012-2015). Moritz joined EMBL-EBI as a Research group leader in August 2015.

field_long_description.safe_value:
The extent of heterogeneity in DNA sequence within human cancers has been difficult to fully assess, due to the absence of methods with sufficient sensitivity to detect minority variants.  For example, next-generation sequencing could in principle detect sub-clonal mutations at any genomic position; however due to amplification errors and inaccuracies in the sequencing platform itself, such approaches are limited to detection of mutations present in >1% of cells.  We have overcome this limitation by developing an approach, Duplex Sequencing, which improves the accuracy of next-generation sequencing by >100,000 fold.  Duplex Sequencing is based upon separately tagging and sequencing the two strands of single molecules of duplex DNA.  True mutations are present at the same position in both DNA strands and are complementary, whereas artifacts arising from amplification or sequencing errors are seen in only one strand.  The calculated error rate of our approach is less than one artifactual mutation per billion nucleotides sequenced. 

We have applied our method to chronic myeloid leukemia (CML); treatment of CML with inhibitors directed against the Abl kinase represents the prototypical targeted cancer therapy.  With Duplex Sequencing, we find that Abl mutations are extremely uncommon at the time of CML diagnosis, and demonstrate that prior reports of frequent Abl mutations in untreated patients may have been limited by artifactual errors arising from RT-PCR amplification.  In contrast, we find that refractory patients who fail therapy frequently possess multiple sub-clonal mutations within the Abl kinase, most of which are below the resolution of conventional approaches.  Further accumulation of mutations is seen in patients with advanced disease, suggestive of progressive intra-tumor heterogeneity during disease progression. In ongoing work, we are applying our technology broadly to multiple cancer types to determine whether the extent of intra-tumor heterogeneity correlates with patient outcome.

field_short_description.safe_value: Direct assessment of sequence heterogeneity in human cancers by Duplex Sequencing

title: Co-evolution of Killer Cell Immunoglobulin-like Receptors and Major Histocompatibility Complex Class I Ligands

field_person_display_title.value: Professor of Structural Biology and of Microbiology and Immunology

field_long_description.safe_value: Functional interactions between Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC) class I ligands and Killer cell Immunoglobulin-like Receptors modulate the development and effector functions of Natural Killer (NK) Cells. These lymphocytes play a prominent role in the immune system and the reproductive system. Both the ligands and the receptors have exceptional genetic variability, involving multiple genes, numerous alleles and rapid evolution. As a consequence, this system of ligands and receptors exhibits considerable species specificity. Our studies have focussed on defining the system in human populations and species of great ape.

title: The EIN1 long non-coding RNA controls the EGF-inducible gene expression programme.

field_person_biography.safe_value:
PhD 2000, University of Cambridge and MRC Laboratory of Molecular Biology. Trinity College Junior Research Fellow, 1999-2005. Beit Memorial Fellow for Biomedical Research, University College London, 2000-2001. MRC Career Track Programme Leader, MRC Laboratory of Molecular Biology, 2001-5 and MRC Programme Leader, 2006-12. field_long_description.safe_value:
Whilst the biological function of many long non-coding RNAs (lncRNAs) remains unknown, recent evidence has suggested that lncRNAs may be important regulators of transcription. This study investigates whether lncRNAs play a role in the transcriptional programme associated with the action of epidermal growth factor (EGF) – an important regulator of cellular growth and movement. We sequenced nuclear RNA in presence and absence of EGF stimulation and we identified 79 lncRNAs regulated by EGF. We observed that lncRNAs upregulated by EGF are also overexpressed in breast cancer cells. Due to its strong induction and high cancer enrichment, we selected EGF-induced lncRNAs 1 (EIN1) for further studies.

Firstly, lack of EIN1 interaction with ribosomes confirmed its non-coding status. Secondly, we observed MAPK-dependent transcription of EIN1 that is independent of protein synthesis. We used newly developed CRISPRi approaches to regulate the expression of endogenous EIN1 transcript. Downregulation of EIN1 led to large changes in the EGF-controlled expression programme. Pathway analysis indicated that EIN1-controlled genes appear to play a role in the regulation of cellular movement. Our results show that lncRNAs are present in the EGF signalling pathway and EIN1 is an example of an lncRNA that regulates the expression of genes downstream of EGF.

field_short_description.safe_value: The EIN1 long non-coding RNA controls the EGF-inducible gene expression programme.

date_range: Tuesday 16 February 2016 14:00 () - Tuesday 16 February 2016 15:00 ()
time_range: Tuesday 16 February 2016, 14:00 (Europe/London) - Tuesday 16 February 2016 15:00 (Europe/London)
title: The transformative genome engineering technology CRISPR-Cas9: lessons learned from bacteria

field_person_biography.safe_value:
Rolf Apweiler is Director of EMBL-EBI, together with Ewan Birney. Prior to this position he was Joint Associate Director, after many years of leading protein resources such as EMBL-EBI's contribution to the UniProt Consortium. Rolf has made a major contribution to methods for the automatic annotation of proteins, making it possible to add relevant information to proteome sets for entire organisms. He has spearheaded the development of standards for proteomics data, and his teams have maintained major collections of protein identifications from proteomics experiments (PRIDE) and molecular interactions (IntAct). He also leads EMBL-EBI’s contribution to the Gene Ontology.

Rolf received his PhD from the University of Heidelberg in 1994, and has been at EMBL since 1987. His major contribution to the field of proteomics was recognised by his election to President of the Human Proteomics Organisation, which he held in 2007 and 2008. In 2012, he was elected as a member of EMBO.

field_long_description.safe_value:
The RNA-programmable CRISPR-Cas9 system has recently emerged as a transformative technology in biological sciences, allowing rapid and efficient targeted genome editing, chromosomal marking and gene regulation. In this system, the endonuclease Cas9 or catalytically inactive Cas9 variants are programmed with single guide RNAs (sgRNAs) to target site-specifically any DNA sequence of interest given the presence of a short sequence (Protospacer Adjacent Motif, PAM) juxtaposed to the complementary region between the sgRNA and target DNA. The system is efficient, versatile and easily programmable.

Originally, CRISPR-Cas is an RNA-mediated adaptive immune system that protects bacteria and archaea from invading mobile genetic elements (phages, plasmids). Short crRNA (CRISPR RNA) molecules containing unique genome-targeting spacers commonly guide Cas protein(s) to invading cognate nucleic acids to affect their maintenance. CRISPR-Cas has been classified into three main types and further subtypes. CRISPR-Cas9 originates from the type II CRISPR-Cas system that has evolved unique molecular mechanisms for maturation of crRNAs and targeting of invading DNA, which my laboratory has identified in the human pathogen Streptococcus pyogenes. During the step of crRNA biogenesis, a unique CRISPR-associated RNA, tracrRNA, base pairs with the repeats of precursor-crRNA to form anti-repeat-repeat dual-RNAs that are cleaved by RNase III in the presence of Cas9 (formerly Csn1), generating mature tracrRNA and intermediate forms of crRNAs. Following a second maturation event, the mature dual-tracrRNA-crRNAs guide the endonuclease Cas9 to cleave cognate target DNA and thereby affect the maintenance of invading genomes. We have shown that the endonuclease Cas9 can be programmed with sgRNAs mimicking the natural dual-tracrRNA-crRNAs to target site-specifically any DNA sequence of interest. Based on this harnessing principle, we proposed that RNA-programmable Cas9 could be useful as a versatile system for genome editing in cells of all three kingdoms of life for biotechnological, biomedical and gene-therapeutic purposes. As demonstrated by a large number of studies published over the last 2 years, DNA targeting by CRISPR-Cas9 has been quickly and broadly adopted by the scientific community to edit and silence genomes in a large variety of cells and organisms, including human cells, plants and mice. I will discuss the biological roles of CRISPR-Cas9, the mechanisms involved, the evolution of type II CRISPR-Cas components in bacteria and the applications of CRISPR-Cas9 as a novel genome engineering technology.

The system is efficient, versatile and easily programmable.

date_range: Tuesday 23 February 2016 14:00 () - Tuesday 23 February 2016 15:00 ()
time_range: Tuesday 23 February 2016, 14:00 (Europe/London) - Tuesday 23 February 2016 15:00 (Europe/London)
title: Metabolic disease signatures translated to underlying mechanisms - a metabolomics approach

field_topic.name: Metabolomics
field_topic.description: Topic concerning the systematic study of metabolites, the chemical processes they are involved, and the chemical fingerprints of specific cellular processes in a whole cell, tissue, organ or organism.

field_long_description.safe_value:
In our research we found that acquired obesity is associated with remodeling of membrane lipids in the adipose tissue. The remodeling may help maintain biophysical properties of lipid membranes, however at the cost of increased vulnerability to inflammation. We also found that the lipid molecular network behind the membrane lipid remodeling is amenable to genetic manipulation. In another study, we identified and validated a serum lipid signature which can be used in the estimation of liver fat and diagnosis of NAFLD, and is also predictive of type 2 diabetes. This signature is not associated with PNPLA3 genotype, suggesting it can be attributed to obesity/insulin resistance rather than liver fat per se. In another study, we applied the genome-scale human metabolic model and integrated it with two independent human experimental settings to study NAFLD. We identified a systemic shift of liver metabolism in NAFLD towards reduced adaptability at the network level, i.e., high liver fat markedly hampers the ability of the liver to adaptively regulate metabolism to meet excessive demands on basic liver functions.

Taken together, our findings suggest that the risk metabolic phenotypes are not always directly associated with the progression to the disease, but may also indicate an activation of the adaptive mechanism. Furthermore, our studies show that acquisition of a specific risk phenotype may lead to global changes in metabolic network properties such as reduced adaptability.

field_short_description.safe_value: Primary obesity is associated with several cardiometabolic co-morbidities including non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) and type 2 diabetes. However, the specific underlying mechanisms linking the expansion of adipose tissue to these co-morbidities are unknown.

title: ORCIDs for Articles & Data Workshop

field_person_biography.safe_value: Jo has been Team Leader for Literature Services at EMBL-EBI since 2009. She is the PI for Europe PMC - the database of abstracts and full-text articles for the life sciences. Prior to joining EMBL-EBI, Jo was a staff scientist at the NCBI, National Library of Medicine, NIH, USA, and was the Editor at Trends in Biochemical Sciences (TiBS), Elsevier. Jo is active in the Force 11 Data Citation Implementation Group, and is interested in text mining as a means to improve the integration of literature with public data resources.She holds a PhD in plant biology from Manchester Metropolitan University.

field_dates_times_info.safe_value:
This short workshop will be in two parts:
13.30-14.30 Overview of ORCIDs and their future development, the THOR project and ORCIDs for data (https://project-thor.eu)
14.30-15.30 Technical: Europe PMC and ORCIDs, and opportunities for integrating ORCIDs with data. Demonstration and hands-on experience with the services for including ORCIDs in data resources

date_range: Tuesday 1 March 2016 14:00 () - Tuesday 1 March 2016 15:00 ()
time_range: Tuesday 1 March 2016, 14:00 (Europe/London) - Tuesday 1 March 2016 15:00 (Europe/London)
title: The genetic basis for evolutionary change in plant morphology: from understanding to reconstructing

field_person_biography.safe_value:
Ewan Birney is Director of EMBL-EBI with Dr Rolf Apweiler, and runs a small research group.

Ewan played a vital role in annotating the genome sequences of human, mouse, chicken and several other organisms; this work has had a profound impact on our understanding of genomic biology. He led the analysis group for the ENCODE project, which is defining functional elements in the human genome. Ewan’s main areas of research include functional genomics, assembly algorithms, statistical methods to analyse genomic information (in particular information associated with individual differences) and compression of sequence information.

Ewan completed his PhD at the Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute with Richard Durbin, and worked in the laboratories of leading scientists Adrian Krainer, Toby Gibson and Iain Campbell. He has received a number of prestigious awards including the 2003 Francis Crick Award from the Royal Society, the 2005 Overton Prize from the International Society for Computational Biology and the 2005 Benjamin Franklin Award for contributions in Open Source Bioinformatics. Ewan was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society in 2014 and a Fellow of the Academy of Medical Sciences in 2015.

field_long_description.safe_value: A key challenge in biology is to understand how diversity in organismal form is generated. Genetic analyses in model systems have identified key regulators that sculpt the body plans of metazoa and seed plants. However, less is known about how the action of such regulators produces particular organ shapes, and how the balance of conservation versus divergence of fundamental developmental pathways generated the tremendous morphological diversity of multicellular eukaryotes. One impediment to answering these questions is the relative paucity of experimental platforms where genetics and developmental biology tools and can be combined effectively to study causal links between genotypic variation and phenotypic evolution in a genome-wide, unbiased fashion, and at different evolutionary scales. To circumvent these problems we developed the Arabidopsis thaliana relative Cardamine hirsuta into a versatile system for studying morphological evolution. We are investigating the morphogenetic mechanisms through which morphology evolved in these species, resulting in simple, undivided leaves in A. thaliana and dissected leaves with distinct leaflets in C. hirsuta. This presentation will discuss our progress towards conceptualising the processes underlying morphological differences of these two species.
