field_person_biography.safe_value: Moritz Gerstung leads a research group at EMBL-EBI investigating the underlying mechanisms of cancer development and seeking to understand the differences in therapy success and outcomes in different individuals. His team develops statistical models for relating different layers of genomic, molecular and clinical data to establish connections between genotype and phenotype, and tools to predict outcomes based on comprehensive, high-dimensional datasets. The group also explores the evolutionary dynamics of cancer. He has a PhD in Computational Biology from ETH Zurich (2012), and carried out postdoctoral work at the Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute (2012-2015). Moritz joined EMBL-EBI as a Research group leader in August 2015.

field_person_biography.safe_value: Dr Alex Bateman joined EMBL-EBI as the Head of Protein Sequence Resources in 2012. He took over from Rolf Apweiler as the PI for the UniProt grant (an international collaboration between EBI, SIB and PIR) and has oversight for protein and ncRNA related databases at EMBL-EBI. Prior to that he managed the production of numerous popular biological databases such as Pfam and Rfam at the Sanger Institute. He was formerly a member of, and Chairman of the ISB's Executive Committee. He was also Executive Editor for Bioinformatics and Editor of NAR's database issue.

field_person_biography.safe_value: I received a bachelor's degree in Computer Science at Rose-Hulman Institute of Technology (Terre Haute, IN, USA) in 2004. From 2004 to 2007, I worked as a research associate at Northwestern University (Evanston, IL, USA) in the lab of Lawrence H. Pinto. There, I performed electrophysiological and behavioral assays on mice to screen for mutations in the visual system. I then returned to school, to receive a master's degree in Biology (Evolutionary and Ecological Sciences) at Leiden University (Leiden, NL) in 2009. I went on to receive a PhD from The Institute of Evolutionary Biology (UPF-CSIC, Barcelona, ES) in 2013 under the supervision of Jaume Bertranpetit and Ludovica Montanucci. My thesis was on the molecular evolution of the proteins of the visual phototransduction pathway, with a focus on the influences of the topology and dynamics of molecular interactions on natural selection. In 2013, I began an ESPOD fellowship under the supervision of Pedro Beltrao (EMBL-EBI), Oliver Billker (Malaria Programme, Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute) and Jyoti Choudhary (Proteomics, Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute). In my present research, I am employing mass spectrometry and bioinformatics to study post-translational modification-based signaling in malaria-causing parasites (Plasmodium spp.).

date_range: Thursday 17 March 2016 14:00 () - Thursday 17 March 2016 15:00 ()
time_range: Thursday 17 March 2016, 14:00 (Europe/London) - Thursday 17 March 2016 15:00 (Europe/London)
title: Normalization of methylation data: how to not throw the baby out with the bathwater

field_long_description.safe_value: The Illumina 450k array is the most popular high-throughput and comprehensive assay for the study of DNA methylation. To date, more than 30,000 samples are readily available from the Gene Expression Omnibus (GEO) and from The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA). As any other high-throughput technology, the 450k array is subject to technical artifacts and needs normalization. It is widely accepted that most cancers show massive changes in their methylome compared to normal samples from the same tissue of origin, and therefore studies of DNA methylation in cancer pose a challenging problem for array normalization. In this talk, I will present Functional normalization, an extension to quantile normalization that removes unwanted technical variation using control probes. Using data sets from TCGA and a large  case–control study, I will show that functional normalization out performs all existing normalization methods with respect to replication of results between experiments, yielding robust results in the presence of batch effects.

field_short_description.safe_value: Normalization of methylation data: how to not throw the baby out with the bathwater

title: Protein-ligand interaction energy for crystallographic model building and validation

field_person_biography.safe_value: Daria Beshnova is a Postdoctoral Fellow (EIPOD) in the Lamzin group at EMBL Hamburg, working on software development for ligand identification within the ARP/wARP software project.

field_topic.name: Structural biology
field_topic.description: Topic concerning the molecular structure of biological molecules, particularly macromolecules such as proteins and nucleic acids.

field_long_description.safe_value:
Title: Protein-ligand interaction energy for crystallographic model building and validation

Abstract: As the number of crystallographic studies undertaken by non-experts is increasing, the availability of powerful validation techniques to verify the correctness of built models before their deposition in the PDB is essential. While for protein models existing approaches allow detection of many classes of errors, for ligand-protein structures the validation protocols are less well developed and the electron density is often difficult to interpret.  We propose a new addition to the crystallographic ligand building in electron density maps that is based on the estimation of the inter-molecular energy of ligand-protein complex formation. We will demonstrate that taking into account three major energetic terms - van der Waals, hydrogen-bonding and electrostatic interactions - helps enhance the interpretation of electron density maps. The method can also be applied for validation of fitted ligands or deposited protein-ligand complexes.

field_short_description.safe_value: Daria Beshnova is an EIPOD shared between the groups of Victor Lamzin (EMBL-Hamburg) and Gerard Kleywegt (EMBL-EBI). She will present an overview of her EIPOD research project.

title: Biological applications of small angle X-ray scattering

field_topic.name: Structural biology
field_topic.description: Topic concerning the molecular structure of biological molecules, particularly macromolecules such as proteins and nucleic acids.

field_long_description.safe_value:
Speaker: Al Kikhney
Title: A quick introduction to small angle scattering
Abstract: Small-angle scattering (SAS) of X-rays and neutrons (SAXS and SANS) is actively used to address increasingly complicated questions in structural biology. SAS allows studying the structure and interactions of proteins, nucleic acids, macromolecular complexes and assemblies in solution under near physiological conditions. I will introduce the basic concepts of SAS and the small-angle scattering biological data bank (SASBDB) - a curated repository of experimental SAS data and derived models.

Speaker: Chris Kerr
Title: ATSAS software suite
Abstract: The ATSAS package incorporates a broad palette of methods for the analysis of isotropic scattering data and is focused on structural characterization of macromolecular solutions. The package encompasses methods for data manipulation and processing, programs for ab initio shape reconstruction, hybrid modelling approaches using high resolution models of subunits, and tools to analyse data from mixtures and flexible systems. The latest version of ATSAS features a number of new modules including AMBIMETER, a program to quantitatively assesses the inherent ambiguity of shape reconstruction from a given SAS pattern; and SUPALM, a program for rapid automated superposition of high and low-resolution models using spherical harmonics.

Speaker:Alejandro Panjkovich
Title: Deciphering conformational transitions of proteins by small angle X-ray scattering and normal mode analysis
Abstract: SREFLEX explores the conformational space of high-resolution models integrating small angle X-ray scattering and normal mode analysis. The hybrid approach can provide direct insight about the conformational changes of biological macromolecules, as illustrated with simulated data and real experimental cases. SASpy, a new PyMOL plugin to manipulate hybrid models through a point-and-click interface, will be demonstrated as well.

field_short_description.safe_value: Several members of the Svergun group at EMBL-Hamburg will present an overview of some of their projects relating to biological applications of small angle X-ray scattering.

field_person_biography.safe_value: Al Kikhney is a Senior Technical Officer in the Svergun group at EMBL Hamburg, working on software development for high throughput biological SAXS.
Chris Kerr is a Software Engineer in the Svergun group at EMBL Hamburg.
Alejandro Panjkovich is an EIPOD postdoc in the Svergun group at EMBL Hamburg.

title: Single-cell RNA-seq-based identification and characterization of  adult stem cells in adipose tissue and beyond

field_long_description.safe_value:
Adult stem cells (ASCs) show remarkable self-renewing, proliferative and multi-lineage differentiation capacities. As such, they are essential for tissue homeostasis and hold great promise for regenerative medicine. However, as ASCs constitute small heterogeneous populations in tissues of complex composition, their identification and characterization remains highly challenging. A good example of such unresolved cell heterogeneity as well as lineage relationships is the adipose system, given the limited, and often conflicting knowledge about the molecular identity of white, brown and brite (brown-in-white) fat progenitors. Yet, understanding how fat cells arise, are maintained, and function in vivo is of great value for tackling global health burdens such as obesity and the metabolic syndrome.

In my talk, I will discuss how we exploited the power of single-cell RNA-sequencing (scRNA-seq) to molecularly dissect the adipose stem cell-enriched stromal vascular fraction. Specifically, I will describe a detailed characterization of precursors resident in mouse subcutaneous fat, arguing for the existence of several cell subpopulations with specific transcriptomic signatures and remarkably distinct differentiation potential. In addition, I will present a machine-learning based approach leveraging on publicly available data, which accurately identifies stem-like cells de novo across various scRNA-seq dissected somatic tissues. The presented findings provide a better understanding of both stem cell and adipose tissue biology and introduce novel approaches for the unbiased identification of ASCs.​

Ewan completed his PhD at the Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute with Richard Durbin, and worked in the laboratories of leading scientists Adrian Krainer, Toby Gibson and Iain Campbell. title: Computational Chemistry and Enzymatic Catalysis – Studies on Nitrile Reductase and HIV-1 Protease

field_person_biography.safe_value: Professor Dame Janet Thornton was Director of EMBL-EBI from October 2001 to June 2015, and played a key role in ELIXIR, the pan-European infrastructure for biological data, since its inception. Her research group focuses on understanding protein structure, function and evolution using computational approaches. After a physics degree she completed her PhD at the UK NIMR before post doctoral studies at Oxford. She then held a joint appointment at University College London and the Bernal Chair in the Crystallography Department at Birkbeck College. Professor Thornton is a Fellow of the Royal Society, a Fellow of the Academy of Medical Sciences, a member of EMBO and a foreign associate of the US National Academy of Sciences.

field_long_description.safe_value:
The great chemical challenge associated with enzymatic mechanisms is to understand why the same chemical reactions are much faster inside enzymes than in aqueous solution. Computational methods have a special role in these efforts, because they can probe the catalytic site of enzymes with atomic detail. Computational chemists are mostly interested in answering two types of questions: a) What is the reaction mechanism of a specific enzyme? and b) What are the catalytic effects common to all enzymes?

In the first case, the objective is to describe the precise chemical steps that transform the reactants into the products. Here, the identification of a low energy transition state structure is the ultimate goal. The mechanism of Nitrile Reductase will be presented as an example of this kind of studies.

The second question is about the identification of general principles of catalysis. The roles of protein flexibility, of electrostatic effects, and of the enzyme scaffold, for example, are still debated in the field. The second part of the presentation will focus on the effect of protein flexibility on the catalytic mechanism of HIV-1 Protease.

title: Natural variation in mutant phenotypes and in drug responses — insights from systematic screens in C.elegans

field_person_biography.safe_value:
PhD 2000, University of Cambridge and MRC Laboratory of Molecular Biology. Trinity College Junior Research Fellow, 1999-2005. Beit Memorial Fellow for Biomedical Research, University College London, 2000-2001. MRC Career Track Programme Leader, MRC Laboratory of Molecular Biology, 2001-5 and MRC Programme Leader, 2006-12. Fellow and Director of Studies, Trinity College, since 2005. Principle Research Associate at the Dept Physics/Cavendish Laboratory, University of Cambridge, 2013-2016. Group Leader at EMBL-EBI and Sanger Institute since 2013.

Dr Sarah Teichmann is a research group leader at EMBL-EBI and senior group leader at the Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute. She is also a Principle Research Associate in the Dept Physics/Cavendish Laboratory, and a fellow of Trinity College, Cambridge. She is a leader in systems biology, which aims to explain how individual molecules within a cell co-operate to produce the cell’s overall behaviour. Her research also offers new insights into how proteins behave. This work could help scientists to predict how proteins interact with each other and design drugs that can interfere with disease processes. After reading the Natural Science Tripos at Trinity College, University of Cambridge, Sarah received her PhD in computational biology from the UK’s Medical Research Council Laboratory of Molecular Biology (MRC-LMB) in Cyrus Chothia's group. Sarah then moved to University College London as a Beit Memorial Fellow in Janet Thornton's group, where her work shed light on how proteins are formed from combinations of basic modules, and how they form networks of interactions in metabolic pathways. She returned to the LMB to set up her own group in 2001, where she focused on transcription factors, proteins that help to control the activity of genes. This included building a database (http://www.transcriptionfactor.org/) that allows researchers to search for genes predicted to encode transcription factors. Seminal work has shown how proteins club together to form larger “machines”, or complexes, by assembling via ordered pathways, and part of this is a further database, 3DComplex.org. Sarah is a co-founder of the state-of-the-art Single Cell Genomics Centre, a joint EMBL-EBI/Sanger initiative to clarify how gene activity is controlled throughout single cells of different types. Her work has been recognized by a number of awards, including the Biochemical Society's Colworth Medal, the Lister Prize, the Royal Society Crick Lecture and membership of the European Molecular Biology Organisation.

field_long_description.safe_value: Many mutations cause genetic disorders. However, two people inheriting the same mutation often have different severity of symptoms and in part this is due to differences in genetic background, that is, to the specific combination of rare and common variants in each individual genome.  Predicting how differences in genetic background impact the severity of inherited disorders is critical for personalized medicine yet little is known about the general underlying mechanisms and there have been no systematic studies in any animal to address this.  I will present the results of the first such systematic analysis of the effects of genetic background on mutant phenotypes in any animal. In addition to this published work, I’ll also present unpublished work using drug screens in C.elegans to complement our genetic analyses. In particular I’ll highlight the differences between what we learn about natural variation in mutant phenotypes and natural variation in drug responses.

field_short_description.safe_value: Natural variation in mutant phenotypes and in drug responses — insights from systematic screens in C.elegans

field_person_affiliation.value: Integrative Computational BioScience (ICBS), Institute of Molecular Biosciences, Mahidol University, Thailand

field_person_biography.safe_value: Duangrudee Tanramluk received her B.Sc. (Chemistry) from Kasetsart University, Thailand, after completed her senior project on conformational analysis based on Density Fucntional Theory calculations of antimalarial compounds. She received her M.Sc. (Biochemistry) from Mahidol University, Thailand, in 2004 with research focus on protein crystallography of P. falciparum Dihydrofolate Reductase – Trimethoprim  complex. In 2005, she also received her M.Sc. (Bioinformatics) from Birkbeck College, University of London, UK, with research focus on analysing amino acid environments in proteins based on statistical approaches under supervision of Profess Nicholas Keep. She received her Ph.D. (Biochemistry) on structural analysis of kinases from the University of Cambridge, UK, in 2010 under supervision of Professor Sir Tom Blundell. Her doctoral thesis won awards from the Sanger-Cambridge PhD Symposium and also the National Research Council of Thailand. Currently, she is a lecturer at the Institute of Molecular Biosciences and also a Principal Investigator of the Integrative Computational BioScience Center, Mahidol University. She developed glasses free 3D laptops for molecular visualization and is the main developer of Manoraa.org website for linking chemical to binding affinity, targets, SNPs and pathways.

field_long_description.safe_value: Protein-ligand interaction analysis is crucial for drug design and protein engineering in order to predict the binding affinity and selectivity of ligands for the target proteins. The MANORAA server, Mapping Analogous Nuclei Onto Residue And Affinity, provides a user-friendly web interface to assist structural study and design of protein-ligand interactions by harvesting information from the PDB. Our flexible SMILES input panel in conjunction with ligand linked out to various databases allows the user to harvest ligand-oriented information such as pathways, off-target proteins, human variants and target systems. The server can drill down to the chemical interactions made by analogous ligand substructures. Conserved features and differences identified from the server will open doors for a robust and insightful analysis of promiscuity, selectivity and trends in binding affinities of the ligand with various proteins.

field_person_biography.safe_value:
I am a scientist working in the  SOLUTIONS EU project (see below). My research interests are the suspectand non-target screening of environmental contaminants, primarily with LC-HRMS/MS but also GC-MS and applying structure generation to the identification of "unknowns". The contribution of mass spectra to open spectral libraries is an essential part of my work and I am an active member in the MassBank consortium, developing RMassBank in a team. I also work on optimizing compound database search strategies for candidate selection and how to communicate the confidence of high-throughput identification results. Together with Steffen Neumann I founded the CASMI contest for small molecule identification in 2012, now into the fourth round. Further interest areas include property prediction for structure selection and incorporating toxicity information in candidate selection for effect-directed analysis to identify potentially toxic compounds.

Within Eawag I am active in the "Non-target" group working closely with Jennifer Schollee, Michael Stravs, Heinz Singer and Juliane Hollender, as well as with Uwe Schmitt from SIS, ETHZ.

I have several collaborations outside Eawag, including Dr. Markus Meringer (DLR: MOLGEN), Christoph Ruttkies (IPB: MetFrag), Dr. Steffen Neumann (IPB: MetFrag, MetFusion, RMassBank), Drs. Werner Brack, Martin Krauss, Tobias Schulze (UFZ, Dept. EDA), Dr. Annemieke Kolkman (KWR), Dr. Chris Steinbeck and team (EBI), Prof. Nikos Thomaidis (U. Athens)

I am a member of the NORMAN Network and the Metabolite Identification Task Group of the Metabolomics Society. I co-guest-edited the CASMI Special Issue in Metabolites and have reviewed for Analytical Chemistry, Analytica Chimica Acta, Chemosphere, Computers in Biology and Medicine, Environmental Science and Technology, Fresenius Environmental Bulletin, Journal of Toxicology, Science of the Total Environment and Talanta.

Ewan Birney is Director of EMBL-EBI with Dr Rolf Apweiler, and runs a small research group.

Ewan played a vital role in annotating the genome sequences of human, mouse, chicken and several other organisms; this work has had a profound impact on our understanding of genomic biology. He led the analysis group for the ENCODE project, which is defining functional elements in the human genome. Ewan’s main areas of research include functional genomics, assembly algorithms, statistical methods to analyse genomic information (in particular information associated with individual differences) and compression of sequence information.

Ewan completed his PhD at the Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute with Richard Durbin, and worked in the laboratories of leading scientists Adrian Krainer, Toby Gibson and Iain Campbell. He has received a number of prestigious awards including the 2003 Francis Crick Award from the Royal Society, the 2005 Overton Prize from the International Society for Computational Biology and the 2005 Benjamin Franklin Award for contributions in Open Source Bioinformatics. Ewan was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society in 2014 and a Fellow of the Academy of Medical Sciences in 2015.

field_long_description.safe_value: The UN has declared access to clean water as a human right, yet we are unable to identify the vast majority of natural and anthropogenic chemicals found in our waterways. This unidentified "dark matter" has the potential to reveal many secrets about human activities, as well as biological processes in the environment. From predicting metabolism, looking for “suspected” substances, comparing water in different continents through to querying the world wide web, chemoinformatic methods have opened up a world of possibilities for higher throughput data exploration in recent years. This talk will highlight novel approaches for compound identification using high resolution mass spectrometry to answer a wide range of water-based research questions, following the three-pronged attack of target (known), suspect and non-target (unknown) screening. The importance of effective suspect screening, database choice, data sharing and communicating the identification confidence, along with common pitfalls and future perspectives, will be highlighted using data from Swiss and European projects.

field_person_biography.safe_value:
With over 20 years of experience in High Performance Computing, Josh currently leads an effort within VMware's Office of the CTO to bring the full value of virtualization to HPC.

Previously, he was a Distinguished Engineer at Sun Microsystems with broad responsibilities for HPC direction and strategy. He joined Sun in 1996 from Thinking Machines Corporation, a pioneering company in the area of Massively Parallel Processors (MPPs), where he held a variety of technical positions. Josh has worked on developer tools for distributed parallel computing, including language and compiler design, scalable parallel debugger design and development, and MPI. He has also worked in the areas of 3D graphics, image processing, and realtime device control. Josh has an undergraduate degree in Engineering from Harvard College and a Masters in Computer Science from Harvard University. He has served as a member of the OpenMP ARB Board of Directors since 2002.

date_range: Tuesday 19 April 2016 11:00 () - Tuesday 19 April 2016 11:30 ()
time_range: Tuesday 19 April 2016, 11:00 (Europe/London) - Tuesday 19 April 2016 11:30 (Europe/London)
title: Electric fields and Enzyme Catalysis: Ketosteroid Isomerase and beyond

field_long_description.safe_value: What physically happens inside an enzyme’s active site to allow such slow and difficult chemical reactions to occur so rapidly?  This question has occupied biochemists’ attention for a long time.  Over the previous decades, computer models of increasing sophistication have predicted an important role for electrostatic interactions in enzymatic reactions, yet this hypothesis proved vexingly difficult to test experimentally.  Recent experiments utilizing the vibrational Stark effect make it possible to measure the electric field a substrate molecule experiences when bound inside its enzyme’s active site.  For several model enzymes, these experiments have provided compelling evidence supporting a strong electrostatic contribution to enzymatic catalysis.  These results raise some interesting new questions, such as: Has electric field catalysis biased the chemical space utilized by nature?  Have active site electric fields been specifically selected for by evolution?  Addressing these questions will require a multi-disciplinary approach that combines computational chemistry with bioinformatics, and I am interested in exploring these possibilities

field_person_biography.safe_value: Professor Dame Janet Thornton was Director of EMBL-EBI from October 2001 to June 2015, and played a key role in ELIXIR, the pan-European infrastructure for biological data, since its inception. Her research group focuses on understanding protein structure, function and evolution using computational approaches. After a physics degree she completed her PhD at the UK NIMR before post doctoral studies at Oxford. She then held a joint appointment at University College London and the Bernal Chair in the Crystallography Department at Birkbeck College. Professor Thornton is a Fellow of the Royal Society, a Fellow of the Academy of Medical Sciences, a member of EMBO and a foreign associate of the US National Academy of Sciences.

title: On being a well-rounded scientist - LOL!

field_person_biography.safe_value: Stephen Curry, Professor of Structural Biology at Imperial College, London, studies the proteins used by RNA viruses such as foot-and-mouth disease virus to understand how these tiny pathogens tick. He writes the Guardian-hosted blog Occam’s Corner, which aims to tell the story of what it’s like to work in science in the UK in the 21st Century and explore the larger social and political responsibilities of being a scientist. He is also a photographer and produced the film "I’m a scientist". Stephen's writing has appeared in The Guardian, Times Higher Education, The Biochemist, Research Fortnight, New Scientist, at Lablit and in the Open Laboratory anthologies of the best science blogging in 2008, 2009, 2010 and 2012.

field_long_description.safe_value: The time-worn view of scientists beavering away in laboratories locked behind the walls of the ivory tower has less and less purchase in the modern world. Whether we like it or not, the arrival of the internet, accompanied by new-fangled things like social media and the impact agenda, is dissolving the boundaries between science and society. In my seminar I will recount my personal journey through this still shifting landscape, one that has been more illuminating and rewarding than I anticipated.

title: Characterizing complex structural variation at the human glycophorin locus

field_person_affiliation.value: Wellcome Trust Centre for Human Genomics

field_person_biography.safe_value:
Ewan Birney is Director of EMBL-EBI with Dr Rolf Apweiler, and runs a small research group.

Ewan played a vital role in annotating the genome sequences of human, mouse, chicken and several other organisms; this work has had a profound impact on our understanding of genomic biology. Ewan’s main areas of research include functional genomics, assembly algorithms, statistical methods to analyse genomic information (in particular information associated with individual differences) and compression of sequence information.

Ewan completed his PhD at the Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute with Richard Durbin, and worked in the laboratories of leading scientists Adrian Krainer, Toby Gibson and Iain Campbell. He has received a number of prestigious awards including the 2003 Francis Crick Award from the Royal Society, the 2005 Overton Prize from the International Society for Computational Biology and the 2005 Benjamin Franklin Award for contributions in Open Source Bioinformatics. Ewan was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society in 2014 and a Fellow of the Academy of Medical Sciences in 2015.

field_long_description.safe_value: Despite an abundance of genetic data, many loci of great biological and evolutionary interest remain a challenge for current sequencing technologies and analysis methods. One such case is the glycophorin gene cluster, which underlies the diverse MNS blood group system and encodes red blood cell surface receptors for pathogens including the malaria parasite Plasmodium falciparum. Nearby signals have been identified in genome-wide scans for both ancient balancing selection and severe malaria susceptibility, but further insight into underlying functional mechanisms is hindered by the homology between the three glycophorin genes. The high level of sequence similarity makes read mapping and variant calling problematic, yet also predisposes the region to frequent non-allelic homologous recombination that can lead to structural variation. To identify such variants, we develop a hidden Markov model that is robust to this homology to infer copy number changes from sequence coverage data. We apply the method to worldwide 1000 Genomes populations and identify multiple large deletions and duplications, corresponding both to known blood groups and novel variation. These are likely to have functional consequences at the red blood cell surface, and the ability to genotype such structural variants at complex loci in emerging databases of human phenotypes may reveal their effects.

date_range: Tuesday 3 May 2016 14:00 () - Tuesday 3 May 2016 15:00 ()
time_range: Tuesday 3 May 2016, 14:00 (Europe/London) - Tuesday 3 May 2016 15:00 (Europe/London)
title: What makes us different? A systems biology perspective on evolutionary innovation

field_long_description.safe_value:
The molecular mechanisms underlying what makes each species unique remain largely unknown. A longstanding theory has been that species evolve new traits through the natural selection of mutations occurring within the functional protein-coding regions of genes. However, this view was significantly challenged by work in recent decades showing that the number of protein-coding genes in a genome of an organism is not correlated with organismal complexity, and that organisms as different as human and chimpanzee share a nearly identical set of protein-coding genes, among other findings. The resulting, more contemporary view, is that modification of cellular networks, such as regulatory networks, may be the principal drivers of phenotypic diversity.

I am exploring the evolution of cellular networks and how it relates to evolutionary innovation. I will describe how changes in regulatory networks can occasionally trigger the emergence of new protein-coding genes with novel functions. I will also present recent work comparing the dynamics of regulatory network evolution across animal lineages. My observations provide evidence for a molecular clock in regulatory network evolution.

title: Diffusion pseudotime reconstructs development and branchings of differentiating single-cells

field_person_biography.safe_value: PhD in Applied Mathematics, University of Cambridge, 2008. Postdoctoral research in the Department of Human Genetics, University of Chicago. At EMBL since September 2010.

field_long_description.safe_value: A central goal in developmental biology is to identify key regulatory genes involved in cellular decision making. With the recent advance of single-cell profiling technologies, a systematic large-scale approach to this question comes into reach, however only snapshots of expression profile of single cells are observed, which are largely unsynchronized with respect to their progress state in the hierarchy of differentiation. A first step towards understanding the dynamics of gene regulation from such data is the inference of continuous and possibly branching differentiation trajectories of different lineages during development. These trajectories may then be used as basis for mechanistic understanding of how gene expression profiles are changing as cells proceed to more committed stages of differentiation. We present a new approach for inferring such branching pseudotime trajectories called Diffusion pseudotime (DPT).

title: The Perseus computational platform for comprehensive analysis of (prote)omics data

field_person_biography.safe_value: Juergen's research group develops computational methods that enable the identification and quantification of molecular components of cells, tissues and body fluids on a large scale. Serving as inputs are large-scale datasets generated by modern omics technologies, like mass spectrometry-based proteomics or next generation sequencing. Their ambition is to elucidate the complex interactions of biomolecules and shed light on their biological functions by means of computational statistical analysis of their quantitative profiles and modeling of the underlying relationships.
Ph.D. Molecular Biology, University of Salamanca, Spain, 2005. Postdoc position at University of Seville, Spain, 2005-2006. At EMBL-EBI since 2006

Mary leads communications activities in the EMBL-EBI External Relations team, liaising with journalists, managing EMBL-EBI's social media presence, and working with the team's graphic designer to produce publications, presentations and content for our EMBL-EBI's global website. Her background is primarily in science communication and scientific, technical and medical publishing. Mary holds a BA in natural science from Hampshire College in the US.

field_long_description.safe_value: One of the biggest bottlenecks in proteomics is the downstream biological analysis of highly multivariate quantitative protein abundance data. In his invited talk, Dr Juergen Cox shows how the Perseus software he developed supports researchers in interpreting protein quantification, interaction and posttranslational modification data. Perseus contains a comprehensive portfolio of statistical tools for high-dimensional 'omics data analysis, covering normalisation, pattern recognition, time-series analysis, cross-omics comparisons and multiple hypothesis testing. Its machine-learning module supports classification and validation of patient groups for diagnosis and prognosis, and detects predictive protein signatures. Perseus features a user-friendly, interactive workflow environment, and provides complete documentation of computational methods used in a publication. All activities in Perseus are offered as plug-ins, and users can extend the software by programming their own and sharing them in a 'plug-in store'. Perseus combines a powerful arsenal of algorithms with intuitive usability by biomedical-domain experts, making it suitable for interdisciplinary analysis of complex, large datasets.

field_short_description.safe_value: Juergen Cox addresses a bottleneck in proteomics: the downstream biological analysis of highly multivariate quantitative protein abundance data. He covers how the Perseus software helps researchers interpret protein quantification, interaction and post-translational modification data.

PhD in Computer Science, Moscow State University, 1987. Postdoctoral research at New Mexico State University, USA. At EMBL-EBI since 1997.

Dr Alvis Brazma oversees the development and services for several major resources, including ArrayExpress, the Gene Expression Atlas and the BioStudies Database. His main research interests concern integrative data analysis to reveal patterns of gene and protein expression in normal and diseased state. He has over 100 scientific publications and is a Principal Investigator on several large collaborative genomics and biomedical projects, including the kidney cancer project of the International Cancer Genome Consortium. Dr Brazma studied mathematics at the University of Latvia, Riga, before obtaining his PhD in computer science from the Moscow State University. He was a lecturer at the University of Latvia and a visiting Researcher at Helsinki University before joining EMBL-EBI in 1997. Dr Brazma was among the first scientists to use microarray data to study gene regulation. In 1999 he founded the Microarray Gene Expression Data society was instrumental in starting ArrayExpress, one of the major international repositories for functional genomics data.

date_range: Tuesday 10 May 2016 14:00 () - Tuesday 10 May 2016 15:00 ()
time_range: Tuesday 10 May 2016, 14:00 (Europe/London) - Tuesday 10 May 2016 15:00 (Europe/London)
title: Extracting molecular function patterns from microbial genomes and metagenomes

field_long_description.safe_value:
How does the environment drive selection of its inhabitants? Molecular functional abilities of individual organisms living in different conditions, e.g. temperature or salinity, are clearly different. Similarly, understanding the molecular functions encoded in the metagenomes of microbiomes (a collection of organisms occupying a specific environmental niche) is vital for the analysis of their behavior and, potentially, synthetic function optimization. The recent emergence of high-throughput genomic sequencing, coupled with the growing analytical capacities, has unlocked new horizons in our understanding of the microbial world. However, making sense of this deluge of data requires efficient and accurate computational techniques. The identification of microbial clades resident in a particular niche is only an estimate of the microbiome’s functional potential. On the other hand, our function-based approach can be applied to individual microbe and microbiome analysis to facilitate assessment of functional diversity.

We previously built fusion (functional similarity-based organism network), a computational method that groups fully sequenced organisms according to their similarity in potential functional abilities, as encoded by their genomes. Currently, we are developing a sequence-based means of identifying the molecular functions encoded in metagenomes via mapping raw genetic reads to the functions of their corresponding “parent” genes. We further estimate the microbiome functional and organismal diversity by mapping the functions identified from metagenome reads onto fusion. By thus analyzing metagenomic data we can identify the diversity of, both, functions and organisms that occupy a particular environmental niche. Our approach recapitulates the functions encoded in the genomes that can be assembled, as well as an additional large set of functions present in the microbiome, but not identifiable via current techniques. By adopting this point of view in analyzing metagenomic data we hope to identify emergent functionality of metagenomes specific to condition (disease, pollution, etc.) versus normal individual samples.

field_person_biography.safe_value:
Rodrigo Lopez joined EMBL-EBI in 1996 as a systems administrator responsible for the deployment of scientific computing and became the External Services Team Leader in 2002. His Web Production team is responsible for the administration of the web infrastructure, development of core software services such as the EBI search engine and EMBL-EBI's job dispatcher, through which many sequence analysis tools run. Many project teams, both externally and within EMBL-EBI, depend on these developments. Rodrigo's team provides institute-wide support and advice on best practises to users. They are heavily involved in the support and in both technical and scientific training of the core software and systems they maintain. 

BSc In Veterinary Medicine, 1984, MSc Molecular Toxicology and Informatics 1987, University of Oslo. At EMBL-EBI since 1995

Ewan completed his PhD at the Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute with Richard Durbin, and worked in the laboratories of leading scientists Adrian Krainer, Toby Gibson and Iain Campbell. He has received a number of prestigious awards including the 2003 Francis Crick Award from the Royal Society, the 2005 Overton Prize from the International Society for Computational Biology and the 2005 Benjamin Franklin Award for contributions in Open Source Bioinformatics. Ewan was elected a Fellow of the Royal Society in 2014 and a Fellow of the Academy of Medical Sciences in 2015.

title: Statistical methods for single-cell RNA-seq

field_person_biography.safe_value: PhD in Applied Mathematics, University of Cambridge, 2008. Postdoctoral research in the Department of Human Genetics, University of Chicago. At EMBL since September 2010.

field_long_description.safe_value: Gene expression studies have yielded a number of fundamental insights that have changed the course of cancer diagnosis, prognosis, and treatment.  In spite of their utility, traditional expression experiments are limited to measurements averaged over thousands of cells, which can mask or even misrepresent signals of interest.  Fortunately, technological advances allow for transcriptome-wide profiling in individual cells.  While the data obtained from single-cell RNA-sequencing (scRNA-seq) is often structurally identical to that from a bulk expression experiment, the relative paucity of starting material and increased resolution give rise to distinct features in scRNA-seq data including an abundance of zeros (both biological and technical), increased variability, and complex expression distributions. These features, in turn, pose both opportunities and challenges for which novel statistical and computational methods are required. In this talk, I will highlight two statistical methods our group has developed for scRNA-seq experiments: the first for normalization and the second for identifying genes with expression patterns that vary across biological conditions.

field_short_description.safe_value: Statistical methods for single-cell RNA-seq

date_range: Tuesday 24 May 2016 14:00 () - Tuesday 24 May 2016 15:00 ()
time_range: Tuesday 24 May 2016, 14:00 (Europe/London) - Tuesday 24 May 2016 15:00 (Europe/London)
title: DisGeNET: a versatile platform to support biomedical translational research

field_long_description.safe_value:
Recent technological breakthroughs have produced an
unprecedented increase in the amount of data on the genetic determinants of
diseases. To unveil the molecular mechanisms that underlie diseases and to
support drug discovery projects, it is necessary to place these data in the
context of the current biomedical knowledge. Despite the large volume of
information available, its analysis and interpretation are hindered because it
is annotated using different criteria and vocabularies and fragmented across
different resources. Furthermore, a large fraction of data on diseases is only
available as free text in biomedical publications. To overcome these
difficulties we have developed DisGeNET as a discovery platform that contains
information on human diseases and their genes. In this talk I will present how
DisGeNET is developed, the different tools to access and exploit the data, and
showcase its application to translational bioinformatics projects

field_short_description.safe_value: DisGeNET: a versatile platform to support biomedical translational research

date_range: Thursday 26 May 2016 09:30 () - Thursday 26 May 2016 10:30 ()
time_range: Thursday 26 May 2016, 09:30 (Europe/London) - Thursday 26 May 2016 10:30 (Europe/London)
title: Optical Computing

field_dates_times_info.safe_value: 26th May from 9:30am to 10:30am in the Kendrew Lecture Theatre

field_long_description.safe_value:
In this interactive seminar, TGAC and Optalysys will introduce and demonstrate a disruptive new technology - a novel optical computing platform that can perform a wide range of pattern matching tasks using lenses, filters and lasers.

At project end in 2017, this device will be compact, powered from a standard mains supply and capable of connection either to a desktop system or large HPC resource.  Such a device has the potential to approach equivalent PetaFLOP rates and to reduce energy costs by 90% over current HPC based approaches.  Furthermore, this could make large-scale alignment, assembly and variant calling analysis a possibility for users without an HPC system.

Everyone is welcome!  The seminar will be particularly of interest to anyone involved in bioinformatics research or High Performance Computing.

For more information and to RSVP please go to: http://www.meetup.com/Genome-Campus-Software-Craftsmanship-Community/events/230568677/

field_person_biography.safe_value: I studied computer science (bachelor degree) and then bioinformatics (master degree) at University of Minho, Portugal. During my studies I took part in several computer science projects and later on I focused in projects related with Bioinformatics and Systems Biology. Consequently, I become familiar with several programming languages, in particular with those that follow the object-oriented paradigm, e.g. Java and C#. During my master I became a member of the bioinformatics group at University of Minho and developed work related with in silica strain optimisation based on over and under expression of genes. On the last year of my master I was granted a trainee position at EMBL-EBI in Saez-Rodriguez Group, where I did my master thesis that focused on the integration of logic modelling and visualisation tools. Now in my PhD project, I intend to focus on the implementation of novel approaches to link different types of biological networks, i.e. link signalling, regulatory and metabolic networks, to increase the predictive power of in silico models. We will address problems like: how to couple the different mathematical formalisms used to represent each layer, or how can we simulate the integrated model?

title: Manuscripts – next generation scientific writing tool from the makers of Papers

field_person_biography.safe_value: Matias completed his PhD at the Sanger Institute under the supervision of Dr Tim Hubbard and Dr Thomas Down, focusing on machine learning and probabilistic inference techniques for DNA motif discovery. His interest in building researcher focused, usable software tools however lead him to join the team building the popular Papers reference manager in an early stage (http://papersapp.com). After an acquisition of Papers by Springer, where Matias continued for several years as the Chief Technology Officer for the Papers business, he co-founded Manuscripts.app Ltd where he now designs, builds and consults together with his EBI alumni co-founder Alexander Griekspoor.

Jo has been Team Leader for Literature Services at EMBL-EBI since 2009. She is the PI for Europe PMC - the database of abstracts and full-text articles for the life sciences. Prior to joining EMBL-EBI, Jo was a staff scientist at the NCBI, National Library of Medicine, NIH, USA, and was the Editor at Trends in Biochemical Sciences (TiBS), Elsevier. Jo is active in the Force 11 Data Citation Implementation Group, and is interested in text mining as a means to improve the integration of literature with public data resources.She holds a PhD in plant biology from Manchester Metropolitan University.

field_long_description.safe_value:
[Manuscripts] (http://manuscriptsapp.com/) is a new kind of writing tool for a scientific author, designed by the team (of Genome Campus alumni) who built the [Papers] (http://papersapp.com/) reference manager.  Our goal with [Manuscripts] (http://manuscriptsapp.com/) is to help an author focus writing time on a narrative about research work, and spend less time on mechanical formatting.

In this talk, I would like to showcase some of the ways in which Manuscripts goes beyond a word processor or a text editor in supporting a scholar:

  • Quickly and easily navigate and manipulate the higher level structure of your document.
  • Format citations & bibliography automatically inserting citations either in-app form or from your Mendeley, EndNote, Zotero, Papers or Bookends library.
  • Create multi-panel figures without leaving the app, and whilst retaining originals.
  • Edit math and syntax highlighted code snippets.
  • Import and export all of MS Word, LaTex, Markdown and JATS XML

I am also excited to show you our recent work that has focused on customising Manuscripts to writing up biomedical and computational work:

  1. Create graphs and table using R or Python with data + scripts embedded (and version controlled) in your document.
  2. Automatically extract biomedical database accessions you type into the app into citations and bibliography entries.
  3. Plugin system for entity extraction + scripting API for reading and manipulating manuscript content.

We would be happy to make a free Manuscripts license available for those attending.

title: Unifying Submission Interfaces to EBI Archives

field_long_description.safe_value:
EMBL-EBI hosts archives for many different assay types. This supports
open data release and provides stable accessions for a group's
experiments. Each archive currently has its own submission interface
and login system. We are starting a project to unify these interfaces.
This will make it possible to make true multi-omic submissions. It
should also make it easier for users to submit data to our archives.

field_person_biography.safe_value: Laura Clarke leads resequencing informatics in the Vertebrate Genomics group at EMBL-EBI. Resequencing Informatics provides data managment, primary analysis and data distribution services for large sequencing consortia like the 1000 Genomes Project, Blueprint, HipSci and FAANG. Laura studied genetics and bioinformatics at Leeds University before joining the Ensembl project in 2001 at the height of the Human Genome Project. She created the primary gene sets associated with the rat, macaque and platypus genomes, and is involved major efforts to identify functional elements in the genomes of cattle, goat, pig and chicken.

Dr Steven Newhouse is head of the Technical Services cluster (formed in 2013) that brings together the systems, web production and web development teams, and leads the Technology and Science Integration group which works to bring technology (both new innovations and established services) from Europe and around the world to further develop and support the Science taking place at EMBL-EBI.

Between 2008-2013 Steven was involved in the leadership of European Grid activities. Initially, as Technical Director of the EGEE-III project and then as Project Director of the EGI-InSPIRE project and Director of EGI.eu, an organisation established in 2010 to coordinate the European Grid Infrastructure (EGI) for the benefit of its stakeholders and its diverse user communities.

Previously, he was a Program Manager in the High Performance Computing group in the Windows Server division at Microsoft, USA. At Microsoft he managed access to the Windows Computer Cluster Server product from non-Windows environments; primarily through the Open Grid Forum's (OGF) High Performance Computing Basic Profile (HPCBP) specification. Between 2008 and 2012 he was a member and then chair of the OGF Board of Directors.

Before starting at Microsoft in 2007, he was Director of the Open Middleware Infrastructure Institute UK (OMII-UK), and on the management or supervisory boards of several major centres and projects within the UK e-Science programme. Previously, he was the Sun Lecturer in e-Science in the Department of Computing at Imperial College London and Technical Director of the London e-Science Centre (LeSC), also based at Imperial, where he did his early research into the modelling of underwater acoustics using high performance computing resources.

date_range: Thursday 16 June 2016 14:30 () - Thursday 16 June 2016 15:30 ()

title: Seasonal rhythms in the Arabidopsis transcriptome and proteome

field_person_biography.safe_value: PhD in Physics, University of Cambridge, 2009. Postdoctoral Fellow, Max Planck Institutes Tübingen, 2009–2012. Research Group Leader at EMBL-EBI since 2012.

field_long_description.safe_value: Plants respond to seasonal cues in order to anticipate the environmental changes that accompany the changing seasons. An important cue in this regard is the duration of daylight - the 'photoperiod'. In Arabidopsis, the transcriptome and proteome show widespread changes in response to photoperiod. We have been using mathematical modelling and analysis of genomic datasets to understand the mechanisms of these responses. We began with well-studied examples of seasonal regulation, such as the timing of flowering and the rate of stem elongation, and are now investigating secondary metabolism and hormone signalling. Furthermore, integrated analysis of transcriptomic and proteomic datasets has uncovered a generic mechanism by which daily rhythms in transcription lead to seasonal rhythms in protein expression. As our mechanistic understanding of environmental responses improves, an exciting possibility will be to model gene expression and predict plant phenotypes in the natural environment.

field_short_description.safe_value: Seasonal rhythms in the Arabidopsis transcriptome and proteome

date_range: Tuesday 21 June 2016 14:00 () - Tuesday 21 June 2016 15:00 ()
time_range: Tuesday 21 June 2016, 14:00 (Europe/London) - Tuesday 21 June 2016 15:00 (Europe/London)
title: Understanding the regulatory potential of Transposable Elements.

field_long_description.safe_value:
Transposable Elements (TEs) constitute almost half of the human genome sequence. Yet TEs have been ignored for long due to reasons including that they are 'junk' DNA. However over the past decade, several studies including from our laboratory have shown that TEs can be functional gene regulatory elements. Towards the goal of comprehensively understanding the regulatory role of TEs, our work investigates three aspects of TEs.

First, we determined the extent to which TEs encode binding sites for TFs in human and mouse cell types. We used data from the ENCODE and Mouse ENCODE projects to analyze 26 TFs in two cell types, in human and mouse. Second, we investigated if TEs contain cis-regulatory modules and can deposit multiple TFs' binding sites and coordinate transcriptional programs across the genome, as postulated by Britten and Davidson. We characterized a module of pluripotency TF binding sites in mouse ES cells and investigated their evolution of their regulatory potential.

Third, we are adopting a massively parallel reporter assay to study the regulatory potential of TEs in a high-throughput manner. We are interested in understanding the correlation between the sequence features in the TEs and their regulatory potential. In addition, we will also be investigating when TEs acquired their regulatory potential – do TEs enter the genome with the potential to regulate gene expression, or do they evolve this potential post-insertion into the genome. Through these studies, we aim to comprehensively analyze the potential of TE sequences to regulate gene expression, and possibly gain a better understanding of why TEs have been retained in the genome.

date_range: Tuesday 21 June 2016 16:00 () - Tuesday 21 June 2016 16:30 ()
time_range: Tuesday 21 June 2016, 16:00 (Europe/London) - Tuesday 21 June 2016 16:30 (Europe/London)
title: Evolution vs Disease: interpreting coding Variants of Unknown Significance

field_person_biography.safe_value: Professor Dame Janet Thornton was Director of EMBL-EBI from October 2001 to June 2015, and played a key role in ELIXIR, the pan-European infrastructure for biological data, since its inception. Her research group focuses on understanding protein structure, function and evolution using computational approaches. After a physics degree she completed her PhD at the UK NIMR before post doctoral studies at Oxford. She then held a joint appointment at University College London and the Bernal Chair in the Crystallography Department at Birkbeck College. Professor Thornton is a Fellow of the Royal Society, a Fellow of the Academy of Medical Sciences, a member of EMBO and a foreign associate of the US National Academy of Sciences.

field_long_description.safe_value: The effect of genome variations on fitness determines health in the short term and evolution in the long term. Unfortunately, often these variations have uncertain significance (VUS) because their context is unique and complex. To interpret coding VUS, we now expand on prior Evolutionary Trace (ET) studies of protein sequence, structure and function. Given that ET discerns functional and structural determinants for mutational design, we now ask whether, conversely, it could help to interpret naturally occurring mutations. We will show a new formalism that models evolution as a genotype to phenotype mapping, and which yields predictions of loss of function in proteins, mortality in patients, and polymorphism frequency in populations that correlate well with observations. This performance is consistent with the CAGI annotation contests, in which independent assessors score competing, blinded methods to predict deleterious mutations. Although past computational tools to assess VUS have a mixed record, these data lend support to this novel view of the Evolutionary Action of mutations on fitness effect, which applies at the molecular, clinical and population scales and which should help assess the clinical harm from human genetic variants.

field_short_description.safe_value: The effect of genome variations on fitness determines health in the short term and evolution in the long term. Unfortunately, often these variations have uncertain significance (VUS) because their context is unique and complex.

field_person_biography.safe_value:
PhD in Computer Science, Moscow State University, 1987. Postdoctoral research at New Mexico State University, USA. At EMBL-EBI since 1997.

Dr Alvis Brazma oversees the development and services for several major resources, including ArrayExpress, the Gene Expression Atlas and the BioStudies Database. His main research interests concern integrative data analysis to reveal patterns of gene and protein expression in normal and diseased state. He has over 100 scientific publications and is a Principal Investigator on several large collaborative genomics and biomedical projects, including the kidney cancer project of the International Cancer Genome Consortium. Dr Brazma studied mathematics at the University of Latvia, Riga, before obtaining his PhD in computer science from the Moscow State University. He was a lecturer at the University of Latvia and a visiting Researcher at Helsinki University before joining EMBL-EBI in 1997. Dr Brazma was among the first scientists to use microarray data to study gene regulation. In 1999 he founded the Microarray Gene Expression Data society was instrumental in starting ArrayExpress, one of the major international repositories for functional genomics data.

field_person_biography.safe_value:
PhD 2000, University of Cambridge and MRC Laboratory of Molecular Biology. Trinity College Junior Research Fellow, 1999-2005. Beit Memorial Fellow for Biomedical Research, University College London, 2000-2001. MRC Career Track Programme Leader, MRC Laboratory of Molecular Biology, 2001-5 and MRC Programme Leader, 2006-12. Fellow and Director of Studies, Trinity College, since 2005. Principle Research Associate at the Dept Physics/Cavendish Laboratory, University of Cambridge, 2013-2016. Group Leader at EMBL-EBI and Sanger Institute since 2013.

Dr Sarah Teichmann is a research group leader at EMBL-EBI and senior group leader at the Wellcome Trust Sanger Institute. She is also a Principle Research Associate in the Dept Physics/Cavendish Laboratory, and a fellow of Trinity College, Cambridge. She is a leader in systems biology, which aims to explain how individual molecules within a cell co-operate to produce the cell’s overall behaviour. Her research also offers new insights into how proteins behave. This work could help scientists to predict how proteins interact with each other and design drugs that can interfere with disease processes. After reading the Natural Science Tripos at Trinity College, University of Cambridge, Sarah received her PhD in computational biology from the UK’s Medical Research Council Laboratory of Molecular Biology (MRC-LMB) in Cyrus Chothia's group. Sarah then moved to University College London as a Beit Memorial Fellow in Janet Thornton's group, where her work shed light on how proteins are formed from combinations of basic modules, and how they form networks of interactions in metabolic pathways. She returned to the LMB to set up her own group in 2001, where she focused on transcription factors, proteins that help to control the activity of genes. This included building a database (http://www.transcriptionfactor.org/) that allows researchers to search for genes predicted to encode transcription factors. Seminal work has shown how proteins club together to form larger “machines”, or complexes, by assembling via ordered pathways, and part of this is a further database, 3DComplex.org. Sarah is a co-founder of the state-of-the-art Single Cell Genomics Centre, a joint EMBL-EBI/Sanger initiative to clarify how gene activity is controlled throughout single cells of different types. Her work has been recognized by a number of awards, including the Biochemical Society's Colworth Medal, the Lister Prize, the Royal Society Crick Lecture and membership of the European Molecular Biology Organisation.

field_person_biography.safe_value: Dr Alex Bateman joined EMBL-EBI as the Head of Protein Sequence Resources in 2012. He took over from Rolf Apweiler as the PI for the UniProt grant (an international collaboration between EBI, SIB and PIR) and has oversight for protein and ncRNA related databases at EMBL-EBI. Prior to that he managed the production of numerous popular biological databases such as Pfam and Rfam at the Sanger Institute. He was formerly a member of, and Chairman of the ISB's Executive Committee. He was also Executive Editor for Bioinformatics and Editor of NAR's database issue.

field_person_biography.safe_value: I studied at the National Autonomous University of Mexico (CCG-UNAM), where I obtained my bachelor degree on Genomic Sciences. After graduation, I worked in the fields of Nutrigenomics and Computational Biology at the INMEGEN; there I learned to analyze microarray gene expression data. In 2012, I enrolled to the program of Applied Statistics (IIMAS-UNAM) to study data analysis techniques that could be used in genomic research. My final project consisted in developing a method to evaluate the quality of genotyping profiles obtained with SNP-microarrays. My interest to study how cells make decisions motivated me to do an internship in Julio Saez's group where I analyzed protein phosphorylation profiles to study the crosstalk between signaling pathways in yeast. As a PhD student in Pedro Beltrao's group, I am using mathematical models to infer the regulatory mechanisms involved in signal transduction that give rise to phenotype variability. For this purpose, we are analyzing protein-phosphorylation modifications.

title: Translating big data from spatial metabolomics into molecular knowledge

field_person_display_title.value: Team Leader, Head of Metabolomics Core Facility

field_person_biography.safe_value:
PhD 2007, St. Petersburg State University.
Postdoctoral Researcher, University of Bremen.
Group Leader, University of Bremen.
Visiting Researcher, University of California San Diego.
Team leader at EMBL since 2014.

field_long_description.safe_value:
Spatial metabolomics is emerging as a powerful approach with high potential to localize hundreds of metabolites directly from sections of biological samples or on biological surfaces. The grand challenges rely in metabolite identification and molecular interpretation of data generated to provide mechanistic, systemic, and spatial understanding of the analyzed biological systems. To address these challenges, novel big-data-oriented bioinformatics is needed as existing computational metabolomics tools fail in face of the sheer size of data reaching hundreds of GBs per sample.

We recently developed bioinformatics for molecular annotation of High Resolution Imaging Mass Spectrometry data, a key analytical technique in spatial metabolomics. The algorithms are efficient and use both spatial and spectral information represented in the data to screen for thousands of metabolites and accounting for their possible modifications. Moreover, we developed an approach to estimate the False Discovery Rate, a cornerstone in all -omics to estimate the confidence of provided annotations yet not existing in metabolomics.

With these bioinformatics developments on hands, currently in the European H2020 project METASPACE (http://metaspace2020.eu) we are developing a large-scale infrastructure for analysis of metabolite content of hundreds of datasets. The key idea is to create a highly-efficient cloud-based system able to 1) metabolically annotate hundreds of datasets from different sources, 2) associate them with biological, technical, and molecular metadata, 3) perform enrichment of ChEBI ontology and metabolic pathways, and 4) wrap everything up into a flexible query system, a sort of a Google Search on the detected metabolite content. This should enable us for the first time to answer questions like: Which metabolites can be detected in a particular organ? How much of data from multi-GB imaging mass spectrometry data can be associated with metabolites coming from a particular biological system? Which structural and functional classes of metabolites are associated with a particular perturbation and what is their localization?

field_short_description.safe_value: Translating big data from spatial metabolomics into molecular knowledge

date_range: Tuesday 7 March 2017 14:00 () - Tuesday 7 March 2017 15:00 ()
time_range: Tuesday 7 March 2017, 14:00 (Europe/London) - Tuesday 7 March 2017 15:00 (Europe/London)
title: Tracking drug action in living cells by thermal profiling of the proteome

field_long_description.safe_value:
Identification of drug targets in situ is one of the major challenges in drug discovery. We developed thermal proteome profiling for unbiased, proteome wide assessment of protein drug interactions in living cells [1]. The technology uses multiplexed, quantitative mass spectrometry in combination with novel biophysical ideas and bioinformatics tools [2]. Latest technological developments and novel therapeutically relevant findings will be presented.

 

[1] Tracking cancer drugs in living cells by thermal profiling of the proteome.

Savitski MM, Reinhard FB, Franken H, Werner T, Savitski MF, Eberhard D, Martinez Molina D, Jafari R, Dovega RB, Klaeger S, Kuster B, Nordlund P, Bantscheff M, Drewes G.

Science. 2014 Oct 3;346(6205):1255784.

 

[2] Thermal proteome profiling for unbiased identification of direct and indirect drug targets using multiplexed quantitative mass spectrometry.

Franken H, Mathieson T, Childs D, Sweetman GM, Werner T, Tögel I, Doce C, Gade S, Bantscheff M, Drewes G, Reinhard FB, Huber W, Savitski MM.

Nat Protoc. 2015 Oct;10(10):1567-93

field_person_biography.safe_value: Professor Dame Janet Thornton was Director of EMBL-EBI from October 2001 to June 2015, and played a key role in ELIXIR, the pan-European infrastructure for biological data, since its inception. Her research group focuses on understanding protein structure, function and evolution using computational approaches. After a physics degree she completed her PhD at the UK NIMR before post doctoral studies at Oxford. She then held a joint appointment at University College London and the Bernal Chair in the Crystallography Department at Birkbeck College. Professor Thornton is a Fellow of the Royal Society, a Fellow of the Academy of Medical Sciences, a member of EMBO and a foreign associate of the US National Academy of Sciences.
